I make sure to prioritize family time and only accept weekend meetings and public appearances that allow them to join me. This way, they know what I do and feel included.

D. The writer

I became a single father after my first marriage broke up, which forced me to focus on my role as a parent. I've made an effort to stay in touch with my daughters, even when we didn't live together. Although I think I could have been a better father, I've always been there for them. I regret not being more structured and providing more boundaries, but I've learned from my mistakes.

E. The TV presenter

**Theatre Reviews**

A. Tamburlaine the Great

Terry Hands' production of Christopher Marlowe's play is a thrilling show. He cut parts of the text to make it faster-paced and more physical. Antony Sher is excellent as the main character, performing acrobatic stunts and demanding the audience's attention. (Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon)

This play by Michael Wall is a powerful exploration of the effects of illness on families. The atmosphere is tense at first, but the play becomes more compassionate as it goes on. (Royal Court Theatre, London)

C. Amphibians

Billy Roche's play is a moving portrayal of the decline of the fishing industry in his hometown of Wexford. The characters are well-developed, and the play has a mix of humor and emotion. (Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London)

D. Murder by Misadventure

This traditional thriller is about two writers who try to kill each other. The twists and turns are cleverly handled. (Whitehall Theatre, London)

E. The Alchemist

Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about con-artists. The actors are excellent, and the play is well-suited to the Barbican's main stage. (Barbican Theatre, London)

F. The Madras House

Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's play is a stylish and well-acted comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. (Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith)

G. Dreams from a Summer House

Alan Ayckbourn's new musical is a charming adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, set in a London suburb. The music is lovely, and the show is a romantic treat. (Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough)

H. The Merry Wives of Windsor

David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but the actors are still enjoyable to watch. (Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon)

I. The Voysey Inheritance

This play by Granville Barker is a great story about a corrupt financial legacy. It's touring the regions and is a must-see. (Apollo Theatre, Oxford)

'Science in Zero Gravity

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students on a unique flight to test their scientific theories. The aircraft, a Boeing KC-135, looked like a normal plane from the outside. But inside, it was transformed into a long, white tunnel with padded walls and few windows. The 13 students from Europe and America had won a competition to participate in this extraordinary flight. They had suggested creative experiments to be conducted in weightless conditions.

The flight began with a steep climb, followed by a sudden loss of gravity. The students felt like they were floating in mid-air. They had 20 seconds to conduct their experiments before the plane started falling back down to Earth. The students from the University of Aachen investigated how metal joins are affected by weightlessness, while those from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails using thin liquid films.

The plane continued to swing up and down, creating a series of curves that made the students feel like they were in a rollercoaster. The Dutch students even tested how cats always land on their feet by releasing a robotic cat, Leonardo. After two hours, the students had experienced the thrill of weightlessness and were eager to continue their scientific research. One student said, "This was an unforgettable experience. I want to become an astronaut even more now."'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a C1 level learner of English:

I had an unusual period in my life when I didn't have any summers. I would spend my summer holidays in New Zealand, which is the New Zealand winter, and I would experience nine winters in a row. My parents suggested that we buy a small plot of land in New Zealand, where my brother, sister, and I could take care of it. The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, as my father was born there. We found a plot of land about 20 miles north of Auckland, in a place called Rangitoupuni. It's not the best land, but it's suitable for planting trees. I've always been interested in land and had experience working on sheep stations and farms in Australia. Planting trees seemed like a great idea, and I was immediately enthusiastic. The rest of the family became enthusiastic too. We started planting in 1968 and by the end of 1972, we had planted the entire 70 acres.

In 1968, it was a very rainy winter in New Zealand. It rained almost every day, which made the planting process challenging. But it was also a happy time, and I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for so long. Every morning, we would get ready for the next planting session, putting on our wet clothes and boots, and struggling with slippery laces. It was a moment of truth every day.

I had a colleague who was an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful because I had never planted trees before. We would carry a bag with as many trees as we could fit and plant them along a straight line. The most difficult part was getting the lines straight. We would set up poles along the line and then plant the trees along it. Once we got into a rhythm, it became easier. I enjoyed the physical work and it made me fit.

After a while, I could plant trees almost automatically. My brain would wander and I would think about life, the natural world, and our place in it. Many of my ideas about the natural world and our connection to it started to form during this time.

I've been back to New Zealand four times since then and seen the trees grow, which has been very satisfying. I've also written a book about my experiences, called Seeing Green. I still feel a strong connection to that place and the idea of people and the earth being connected.

Here is a simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Our Farm's Unlikely Residents'

Six years ago, my husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm', where we care for orphaned animals. Recently, one of our helpers brought us a cardboard box containing three small grey badger cubs. They were only about eight inches long and had never been outside their underground sett before. Their mother had been killed, and they were cold and hungry. We named them Primrose, Bluebell, and Willow.

We fed them with a syringe at first, but soon they were able to drink from a bottle. It was important to make sure they didn't drink too fast, as this can cause lung problems. Unfortunately, one of the cubs, Willow, died from a lung infection. We were devastated, but we continued to care for the other two.

A few days later, a local farmer found another male badger cub, which we named Willow II. He was a bit younger than the others and had a harder time eating. We had to move the bottle around and squeeze it to get him to drink. It took him a while to learn, but eventually he was eating well.

As they grew, the cubs became more active and started to explore their surroundings. They loved to play in the long grass of our cider orchard, chasing each other's tails and getting excited. We would join in, but Derek was a bit clumsy and sometimes got bitten.

As the summer was very hot and dry, we noticed that other badgers were visiting our field, probably searching for food. We were worried that they might attack our cubs, so we built a special enclosure for them with a badger gate and sheet metal to keep them safe.

The local press took pictures of us walking the badgers, and the response was overwhelming. We started an appeal to build a sett for the badgers, and with the help of local firms and a bus company, we were able to build a special home for them. The badgers loved their new sett and would explore it before going on their nightly walks.

Now, the cubs are fully grown and have moved into their new home. We still see them occasionally, especially Bluebell and Willow II, who come to say hello before they go off into the night. They have their own territory now, and we're happy to see them thriving.

I have minimised the changes to the factual content of the passage to ensure that the questions associated with it remain answerable. I have used simpler vocabulary and sentence structures to make it more accessible to a learner of level C1 on the CEFR.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to recreate Sir Edmund Halley's journey to chart compass variations. Halley, an astronomer, is famous for the comet that bears his name, but his work on charting compass variations was also very important. Without this knowledge, sailors couldn't correct their compasses, which made it difficult to navigate the oceans and determine their longitude.

Halley's journey was the first dedicated scientific expedition on the seas, and he became the first civilian to be appointed naval captain to pursue this research. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands, Rio de Janeiro, and other places, collecting data on the variations of the compass. He published his findings in a chart that was used by sailors for over a century.

Dr. Clark is planning to commemorate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing his route. He will use more advanced instruments to collect data on the magnetic field of the Earth, which is constantly changing. This data will help to refine the existing model of the Earth's magnetic field.

Dr. Clark became interested in Halley's work while working at Halley Station in Antarctica. He believes that Halley's journey deserves to be recognized, and he is willing to spend eight months at sea to make it happen. He is planning to divide the journey into four stages, with four different crews.

Dr. Clark's expedition will not only pay tribute to Halley's achievement but also contribute to scientific research. He hopes to fill gaps in the data collected by a Danish satellite and provide a comparison with ground-based measurements.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level (Common European Framework of Reference for Languages):

Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their impressive tails to the hens. This has puzzled scientists for a long time, as it seems like a waste of energy. The question is, how do they get away with it? Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team are trying to find the answer.

Charles Darwin believed that living creatures evolved over time through a process called natural selection. He thought that the best-adapted individuals were more likely to survive and have offspring. However, this doesn't explain why peacocks have such extravagant tails. Darwin proposed that there must be another mechanism at work, which he called "sexual selection". He believed that females choose males with attractive features simply because they are attractive.

Another scientist, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He thought that females must be choosing males with long tails because they have some other quality that is not immediately obvious to humans, but is important for survival. Today, scientists are still trying to figure out why peahens prefer peacocks with long tails.

Marion Petrie and her team are studying the behavior of 200 peafowl at Whipsnade. They want to know if peahens really do choose males with the most impressive tails, and if those males have any other advantages. They have observed that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are related to the length of the tail. However, they are still unsure if the males with the best tails are also healthier or more successful in other ways.

One scientist, William Hamilton, has suggested that showy males may be less likely to have parasites, and their bright plumage may advertise their good health. The researchers at Whipsnade are testing this idea by comparing the offspring of attractive and unattractive males. They are also exploring the idea that the peacocks' tails may be a "runaway" phenomenon, where the females' preference for long tails leads to a feedback loop that drives the evolution of even longer tails.

Note: I made minor changes to the original text to simplify the language and sentence structure, while preserving the main ideas and factual content. I also removed some technical terms and jargon to make the text more accessible to a C1-level learner.<|eot_id|>

MY BOAT, THE WESTERMAN

Tom Cunliffe believes that the perfect boat combines old and new design. He built his own boat, 'The Westerman', to prove it. This week, the London Boat Show is showcasing modern yachts with advanced technology. In contrast, my boat is anchored in a quiet creek off the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like a 100-year-old boat and might seem old-fashioned. However, it has the best of both worlds: traditional design and modern know-how.

Despite the benefits of modern technology, it can sometimes make sailors forget the challenges of life at sea. I believe that a boat should be a boat, not a floating home. It should have a stove for warmth, comfortable berths, and a bit of struggle with the sails. I learned this from my previous boat, Hirta, which I sailed around Britain for a TV show. She was simple, but kind and easy to handle.

I had to say goodbye to Hirta due to a back injury, and I couldn't find a suitable replacement. So, I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman was designed by Nigel Irens, who used a combination of traditional and modern methods. The design was refined through a process of trial and error, with the help of computer-assisted design programs.

The Westerman has performed well in racing and has a timeless, peaceful atmosphere. She was designed as a sailing boat, not a floating home, and this is what makes her special. She is made of timber treated with a special glue, making her resistant to water. This means she has the benefits of a modern boat, but looks, feels, and sails like a traditional one.

A. HENLOW GRANGE

I spent six days at Henlow Grange, a beautiful 18th-century house. My room was very comfortable and relaxing. I took part in various activities, including body conditioning classes and yoga. The instructors were highly trained and made me feel very supple. The hotel offers a range of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and manicures. The staff were friendly, professional, and made me feel at ease. The atmosphere was lively and enthusiastic. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy.

B. SHRUBLAND HALL

Shrubland Hall is a peaceful and relaxing place. The moment I arrived, I felt calm and serene. The hotel has a large library, a charming conservatory, and plenty of space. Everyone is given a medical check-up upon arrival, which includes an examination and a check on weight and blood pressure. The staff are very professional and helpful. The food is healthy and delicious. I was impressed by the attention to detail and the variety of treatments available.

C. CAREYS MANOR

Careys Manor is not a health farm, but it offers a range of spa facilities. The hotel is comfortable and luxurious, with a beautiful lounge and a fully-equipped gym. The food is delicious, but if you're counting calories, you may want to opt for a 'health-conscious' diet. The hotel has a spa bath, steam room, and treatment rooms. I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury and was able to work on it during my stay.

D. CLIVEDEN

Cliveden is a majestic country home and hotel that treats its guests like royalty. The hotel offers a range of health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, and swimming pool. The surroundings are beautiful, with stunning woodland walks and gardens. The hotel has a highly-acclaimed restaurant with delicious food. I enjoyed a facial and aromatherapy massage, and the staff were very friendly and professional.

E. SPRINGS HYDRO

Springs Hydro is a modern and purpose-built health spa. The hotel offers a range of treatments, including aromatherapy massages and beauty treatments. The staff are friendly and efficient, and the facilities are luxurious. The carrot cake is delicious, but be careful not to overindulge! I had a wonderful time and would recommend this hotel for a relaxing break.

Here is the simplified text for a C1 level learner:

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't developed many differences. In fact, we are still 98% identical to chimps genetically. This means that the things that make us human must be due to a small number of genes. This is a big responsibility for those genes.

Scientists have been studying animal behavior and finding that many things we thought were unique to humans are not. For example, chimps use tools and sea otters use rocks to crack open shells. Monkeys even have a simple language with different sounds for warning calls.

The only things that seem to set us apart from animals are art and language. However, our ancestors didn't create art for the first 6.9 million years. The earliest evidence of art is from around 35,000 years ago, in the form of cave paintings and carvings.

There are three main differences between human art and animal art that are often mentioned: human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure, and it's transmitted by learning. Let's examine these claims.

Firstly, some people argue that human art is useless, unlike animal behaviors that help us survive or pass on our genes. However, human art can communicate something to others, even if it's not a survival function.

Secondly, it's possible that animals create art for aesthetic pleasure, even if we can't ask them about it. For example, birds sing for mating and territorial purposes, but they also sing for the joy of it.

Lastly, human art is learned, whereas some animal behaviors are instinctive. However, human art styles change quickly, and even animals can learn new behaviors.

The article concludes by mentioning a famous experiment where chimpanzees created art and sold some of their paintings. This blurs the distinction between human and animal art, as the chimpanzees created art for their own satisfaction and didn't intend to communicate with others.

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It's also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale. These days, you don't often hear about big adventures or brave explorers like in children's stories. But Charles Blackmore is an exception. He led an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert, also known as the Desert of Death.

The team consisted of four Britons, an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The handlers had never worked with camels before, which could have been a big problem. The team set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of desert. Charles Blackmore has written a book about their journey.

Charles was about to leave the Army after 14 years and wanted to do something new. He wanted to prove to himself that he could do it. His wife, Tina, was worried about him because nobody had ever crossed that route before. It took them 59 days to complete the journey. They faced many challenges, such as dysentery, extreme temperatures, and dehydration. But they were lucky and found water when they needed it.

The team had to overcome many obstacles, including sandstorms, steep dunes, and blisters. Charles was scared at the beginning, but as they walked, he became more confident. When they finally finished, they were thin but strong. Charles felt proud of what they had achieved.

Looking back, Charles thinks about the challenges they faced and how they overcame them. He says that the experience helped him find peace with himself. He still misses the sense of adventure and purpose that came with the expedition.<|eot_id|>

I think the marketing experts are manipulating us. When my word processor started making strange noises, I decided to abandon it and go back to doing things by hand.

I've discovered that I can enjoy activities like sewing, reading, and spending time with family and friends without relying on technology. I've also found that sewing by hand is a calming and satisfying experience. I can listen to the radio or watch TV while I sew, and it's a lovely feeling to sit by the fire with a cup of tea.

I've started to question whether we really need all the modern appliances we have. Do we need a freezer, a microwave oven, or a powered lawnmower? We could save a lot of money by using simpler, manual methods.

'Eccentrics are people who behave in a way that is not usual or normal. But what is normal, really? We all have our own quirks and things that make us different. Some people love to enter competitions, collect unusual items, or write letters to the press about things that bother them. Being eccentric is about being ourselves and standing out from the crowd. However, most of us have a strong desire to fit in and be accepted by others. This desire is often stronger than our desire to be different.

Notice how people who have unusual hobbies or interests often gather together with others who share their passions. They form groups and clubs to discuss their common interests. The important thing is that they find others who understand and accept them for who they are.

We all have a mix of two tendencies within us: the desire to be individual and the desire to fit in. While we may feel the need to assert our individuality, we also feel the pressure to conform to societal norms. This tension is natural, and it's something that we all experience.

Some people have made a name for themselves by being true to themselves and following their own path. Bob Dylan, for example, is a famous singer who has always stayed true to his own vision.

Eccentricity is not just about doing unusual things for attention or to shock others. It's about being natural and genuine. True eccentrics are not trying to be different; they simply are different because of who they are. They don't worry about what others think of them, and they just do what feels right to them.

This is what sets eccentrics apart from others who may be trying to make an impression or escape from society. Eccentrics are not aware of the world around them; they just live their lives according to their own rules.'<|eot_id|>

**Bruce Pearson**

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the impact of book reviews on their commercial success. Here's what they said.

Publisher A Reviews are crucial for publishers. A study found that when people buy a book, they often cite reviews as the main reason. Authors and publishers have different reactions to reviews. Publishers are more concerned with the number of reviews a book gets rather than their content. A mix of positive and negative reviews can actually increase sales as readers want to form their own opinion.

Publisher B Publishers and the press have different goals. Newspapers aim to entertain their readers, while publishing houses want to promote their books. Book reviewing has improved over the years, becoming more diverse and less elitist. However, there is still a lack of coverage for paperbacks. Publishers need reviews to promote their books and authors.

Publisher C Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Without them, publishers would struggle to promote their books. Favourable reviews can greatly increase sales, as readers trust the opinions of literary editors. Publishers often look for quantity rather than quality in reviews.

Publisher D The relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain is complex. In the US, a single review in The New York Times can make or break a book. In the UK, bookshop staff often ignore reviews, and it can take time for authors to gain recognition. Some books that receive poor reviews can still be bestsellers.

Publisher E While all publishers and writers dream of glowing reviews, they don't always guarantee success. A biography I published received excellent reviews, but the book was a flop. The public may feel they don't need to buy the book if they've read the reviews. The name of the reviewer can still influence people's decisions, but it's not the only factor.

Instead of finding a new job, Evans decided to take a risk and travel to America for three months to research his first novel. He had always been fascinated by the story of a horse whisperer, someone who could calm a wild horse just by talking to it. Evans spent the spring driving across the United States, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He was alone and struggling financially, but he was determined to write his novel. When he returned home, he wrote the first half of the book. His bank manager was getting impatient, and Evans needed to know if his book was worth continuing to work on. He showed his manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent, and the agent thought it was good enough to sell.

The agent sent the manuscript to seven publishers, and within a week, Evans received an offer of $75,000. The book was then sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $315 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. The book became a huge success, and Evans was in high demand. He turned down an offer to write the screenplay for the book and instead decided to focus on writing his next novel.

Volunteer Tourism: A Double-Edged Sword

Four academics discuss the impact of international voluntary work. Some argue that the actual contribution to development is limited. While volunteers can participate in building homes or schools, they often pay a significant fee for the opportunity, which could be used to fund more labor-intensive projects. This is particularly true for gap-year volunteers, who usually lack specialized skills or experience. This raises questions about the true motivations behind gap-year volunteering: is it driven by a genuine desire to help others or a desire to gain personal benefits?

On the other hand, volunteering can lead to greater international understanding, improved conflict resolution, and increased global civic engagement. In this scenario, the benefits extend beyond individual volunteers to host communities and contribute to the greater good. However, if volunteering is dominated by individuals from wealthier countries, it may only benefit those who already have access to international opportunities, leaving others behind.

At its worst, international volunteering can be exploitative, paternalistic, or self-serving. On the other hand, it can provide valuable technical assistance and promote cross-cultural exchange. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness of and inspire a lifelong commitment to addressing global inequalities and unsustainable development.

Volunteer tourism often fits with the trend of people seeking to make a positive impact. While this can be a commendable act, it can also bypass democratic processes and reduce development to individual acts of charity. The marketing of volunteer tourism as a means of sustainable development is problematic, as it can distract from addressing the root causes of poverty and inequality.

I made the following changes:

1. Simplified vocabulary: Replaced complex words like "altruism," "cultural capital," and "imperialist" with more accessible alternatives.

"Choosing a Good Clock Radio

Many people listen to the radio in the morning to help them wake up. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, consisting of myself, Tom Granger, and Paul Bridges, tested five different models. One model had a 'dual alarm function' that allowed you to set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. However, this feature did not work as expected. The instruction booklet advised using it to set different wake-up times, but who has time to plan their day that precisely?

This model also had a cassette player, which was a nice bonus. You can fall asleep listening to your favorite music and wake up to a peaceful morning without the sound of news. The radio quality was excellent, but the clock radio itself was quite large. Paul Bridges said he wanted a clock radio that left enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone.

We all liked the digital display of this model, with its clear numbers on a gentle green background. The snooze button was easy to use, even with your eyes shut. However, the smooth buttons encouraged us to play with them like a piano, which made it difficult to follow the instruction booklet.

The clock had a self-power backup, which meant you didn't have to reset it if someone unplugged it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner. We all found it a bit tricky to set up, but once we got the hang of it, we felt proud of ourselves.

One model had an extra built-in lamp, which Tom Granger found tacky. He had to read the instruction booklet twice to get it to work, and the lamp was hard to position. Paul Bridges liked the idea of the lamp but found the radio hard to tune. The buzzer was loud and annoying, but the radio quality was good.

Another model was the third most popular on the market. It was designed for young people, with a brightly colored casing and matching strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it didn't blend into the background like the other models. The traditional design made it easy to set up without reading the instruction booklet.

The simplest and cheapest model we tested had old-fashioned dial tuning, which Tom Granger preferred. He found it more intuitive and reliable than modern push-button tuning. The radio quality was good, and the buzzer worked well, waking me up in just two beeps!"<|eot_id|>

I've always loved walking long distances. I even walked across Australia once! It was the hardest experience of my life, but I got the record. Men often underestimate women and think we're more likely to fail, so it's harder to get sponsors.

E. Lisa, 26, saloon car racer
Some men can be very competitive and aggressive when they're driving. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. As a woman, I face more challenges, but I love the thrill of racing and the feeling of perfection.

F. Alison, 28, triathlete
I train a lot, swimming, cycling, and running. It's hard work, but I feel happy and fulfilled when I'm fit. Sometimes I get tired and fall asleep at my desk, but it's worth it. I love the social aspect of racing and the feeling of achievement."

Here is the simplified text for a C1 level learner:

**Talking shop: How supermarkets and chainstores make you spend**

Have you ever gone to a store and left with more than you planned to buy? Shops use various techniques to encourage you to spend more. Here are some of the ways they do it:

**A. Freshness matters**

Supermarkets know that customers want fresh produce. They often put fruit and vegetables near the entrance and display fresh bread to make you feel like you're getting a good deal. The color of the store can also influence your mood, with green being associated with freshness.

**B. Displaying products effectively**

The location of products in a store is crucial. Supermarkets use computerized stock control to see which products sell best and place them in the most visible areas. This is especially true for high-profit items or fast-selling products.

**C. Placing staples strategically**

Supermarkets put low-price staples like bread, tea, and sugar in hard-to-reach places, making you pass by more expensive items on the way. Chainstores also hide their high-priced products to encourage customers to search for them.

**D. Less sells more**

Some chainstores display limited quantities of products to make them seem exclusive. This approach, popularized by Next, creates a "boutique" feel and makes customers feel like they're getting something special.

**E. The power of price**

Food shoppers are more concerned with the overall cost of their shopping trip than individual prices. Supermarkets balance high-markup items with low-markup staples to keep customers coming back.

**F. Pricing matters**

In chainstores, individual prices are important, and customers are more likely to notice price differences. This is also a way to reduce theft among employees.

**G. Lighting the way**

Supermarkets and chainstores use lighting to create a welcoming atmosphere. Chainstores aim for natural lighting, while supermarkets use special lighting to highlight fresh produce.

**H. Guiding customers**

Chainstores use different carpeting to guide customers through the store. This "Yellow Brick Road" approach can be effective, but some customers may resist exploring the sales areas.

**I. In-store promotion**

Supermarkets use giant photos and videos to promote products, while some stores are testing video trolleys with screens that advertise products as you shop. These tactics aim to increase impulse buys and boost sales.

To simplify the text for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR), I will make minor changes to the vocabulary, sentence structure, and wording while preserving the factual content of the passage. Here is the simplified text:

Apples have been with us for thousands of years. They come in many different shapes, sizes, and colors. However, the late 20th century is in danger of losing this diversity. In prehistoric times, humans ate apples and threw away the seeds. They also left behind apple remains around their homes in Switzerland and Italy.

The Romans brought fruit-growing skills to Britain, including making cider. They introduced the dessert apple, Decio, which was later developed into new varieties. British monks continued to experiment and create new apples, and many of these varieties are still grown today.

In the 13th century, several types of apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a favorite dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was another popular apple that was sold in markets. However, the country faced many challenges, including droughts, the Black Death, and wars, which reduced apple production and led to more imports.

In the 16th century, Henry VIII ordered his chief fruiterer to visit France and learn about apple cultivation. This led to the introduction of new varieties, including the famous Pippins. Apples became so popular that they were taken to new lands by settlers, including Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand.

In the 19th century, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt discovered a new apple variety, which he named 'Hawkey'. The apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world. Another famous apple variety was discovered by Maria Anne Smith in Australia. She named it 'Granny Smith' and it became famous worldwide.

Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most commercial apples come from just a few varieties. This has led to a loss of diversity and a reduction in the number of apple varieties. However, consumers are starting to demand more variety, and it is essential to protect and preserve natural diversity for the benefit of all.

However, Richard believes that Kenyan success cannot be attributed solely to altitude. Kenyan runners are known for their simple and uncomplicated approach to the sport. They seem to love competing, and their diet and lifestyle are also simple. But the least discussed aspect of their success is how they train.

Richard stayed with the Kenyan national team at their training camp, which is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya. The camp is basic, with few comforts. The athletes live among the college students and have a simple daily routine. They have three workouts a day, including a morning run, interval training, and a steady run in the afternoon. The daily routine starts at 6 am and includes a total distance of about 40 kilometres.

In his free time, Richard appreciated the simplicity of the lifestyle at the camp. He enjoyed taking a splash of water on his face and brushing his teeth for breakfast, and the meals were simple and traditional. After the day's training, they would drive to a nearby stream to bathe. Richard left the camp with a new appreciation for Kenyan success, which he believes is due to a combination of factors, including the purity and simplicity of the mountainside lifestyle, the gruelling workouts, and the passion for success.

Here is a simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Advertising is not doing well. It's not just because of the economic recession. The problem is that advertising has not kept up with the changes in the economy. Advertisers like to think about big markets and big media, but as there are more brands and media, the target audience has become smaller. Even big brands rarely target their campaigns at specific groups of people.

Think about your own shopping habits. You might buy 30-50 items from a supermarket, but most of them will not be advertised brands. You might only buy a few hundred different brands in a year. Compare this to the 32,500 brands that are advertised, and you can see that most of the advertising is wasted.

In fact, research shows that people only remember a small number of advertisements they see. The rest are ignored. This means that advertising is inherently wasteful. However, it is still a cost-effective way to reach a large number of people, even if not all of them will respond.

The key is to target the right people with the right message. This can be difficult, as advertisers can't know in advance who will respond to their advertising. Even direct mail shots, which are targeted, don't always get a 100% response. The difference between media advertising and face-to-face selling is that a salesperson can know exactly who will respond, but an advertiser can't.

To make advertising more effective, advertisers need to target their messages more precisely. This might involve using new technologies, such as social media, or analyzing data about their customers. The goal is to reach the right people with the right message, rather than trying to reach everyone with a broad message.

"I thought giving up smoking would make everyone happy, but one of my colleagues was furious. 'Why didn't you stop years ago?' she asked. I couldn't explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to a non-smoker in just a few hours. I attended a stop-smoking session, which was a combination of group therapy and hypnotherapy. I didn't intend to stop smoking and didn't even want to. I resented the pressure from anti-smoking groups and thought I was healthy enough not to need to quit. On the day I attended the session, I was writing an article about people trying to give up smoking. I told the counsellor I wouldn't be trying to stop, as my motivation was to write about the experience, not to quit. The session was unusual, as we were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted. However, when I was asked to smoke, I felt reluctant, as did the others. I think what happened was that the idea of stopping made sense intellectually. It became appealing to me, just like the challenge of smoking had become when people opposed it. The possibility of not being a smoker made me feel powerful. It was a secret feeling that had nothing to do with anyone else. Quitting was surprisingly easy. The physical craving for nicotine faded after a few minutes, and I only experienced it for a few days. I thought my work would be difficult to do without cigarettes, but it wasn't a problem. The hardest part was finding things to do on weekends, as I had always used smoking as a way to fill my time. I do miss smoking, but not too much. I have to get used to new situations, like eating out or waiting for a plane, which I would previously have used as an excuse to smoke."

Her story can teach us about the importance of balancing work and personal life, and how creative genius can be achieved through hard work and dedication.

Margaret's ability to locate water is not unique; many people have been fascinated by this skill for centuries. Anthropologists and writers have studied it, but the exact reason behind it is still unclear. Margaret calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment", and it's essential to her business's success.

We swapped lives for a day! Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? Maybe you'd like to do something different for a change? We arranged it for four people - read what happened.

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother of two, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, a 30-year-old waitress at a popular London restaurant and entertainment complex. Amanda's story

I had never been in a place like that before. It was very noisy and dark, with so many people. It was a big change from my hometown, and to be honest, I wasn't sure I could handle it! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I only had 15 minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to fall off the tray and spilled everywhere. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first! By the time the restaurant opened at 11:30 am, a queue had formed outside, and I started to feel really nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but that wasn't a problem because everything was automated. After a few hours, my feet were really sore, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. Every time a customer talked to me, I had to say 'Excuse me?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was exhausted and longed to soak my feet in a bowl of hot water. I didn't realize how tiring waitressing would be. I always thought it was a job for people who are shy, but in fact, you need to be quite outgoing and able to stay calm under pressure.

Cindy's story

I was a bit nervous about being a mother for the day, but I was also looking forward to it. I was warned that the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. Little did I know! As Amanda left to go to the restaurant, I had to get the girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie and went to the supermarket, then took her home for lunch. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming as loudly as possible! I decided to take the laid-back approach, thinking they'd soon get tired. Wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they beat me, hands down! After much persuasion, I managed to get them into bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun and games started! How many glasses of water can a child drink, for goodness' sake? Of course, I realized it was just a ploy to get them to come downstairs and watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I didn't realize how tiring it could be to look after two small children. You don't get a moment to yourself - and the sense of responsibility is overwhelming. Despite all the chaos, I really enjoyed the day.

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, a 30-year-old teacher at a primary school. Rosemary's story

On the farm, I have to get up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a luxury! But I dawdled for ages about what to wear. I couldn't show up in overalls and boots, could I? Looking at a sea of faces - about 400 pupils - at assembly, I hoped I blended in and that my fresh complexion didn't make me stand out as being straight from the farm. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded according to difficulty - quite different from when I was at school and we had to recite tables in unison! Then I helped out with a nature project - identifying and feeding species of snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looking forward to an hour's break, but the teachers only have about five minutes to eat their meal. There's so much to do before classes start again. Hardenberger's love for the trumpet started when he was eight years old. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's playing, gave him a real trumpet as a Christmas gift. The boy was instantly hooked and never stopped playing. His mother contacted the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, who became his teacher, Bo Nilsson. Nilsson was a talented musician who was passionate about the trumpet and recognized Hardenberger's natural talent.

Hardenberger believes that the trumpet is a primitive instrument with imperfections, and he has learned to accept and work with these imperfections. He has always thought of himself as a solo artist, inspired by French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo work. Hardenberger's parents supported his ambition to become a professional trumpet player, and he studied in Paris with Pierre Thibaud, who confirmed his decision to pursue a solo career.

I work closely with our marketing team and advertising agencies to develop a strategy for the membership program. I have meetings throughout the day and make myself available to answer any questions. I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues that arise. I usually leave the office between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

B. Record Company Executive

I start my day at 10:00 am by going through the post, which includes demo tapes, letters from producers, and information about concerts. The phone starts ringing at 10:30 am, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for specific artists. I listen to demo tapes carefully, as they contain people's life work. I instinctively know if the sound is suitable for our record label. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album, choosing the songs, producer, and additional musicians. I communicate my vision for the album to the rest of the company for marketing and sales. I also oversee budgets and spending. I often attend gigs and sometimes visit artists in the studio. My social life revolves around my work, and I usually don't get home until 1:00 am.

C. Sales Director

I wake up at 8:00 am and arrive at work at 9:30 am. I start by opening the post and checking my diary for any meetings scheduled for the day. I love taking clients around the showrooms, as it's rewarding to reach an agreement and know the furniture will go to a good home. We sell antiques ranging from £1,000 to £6,000 and source them from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Some items require restoration, which I coordinate with our in-house restorer and external specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette during breaks to stay updated on the industry. I spend about an hour doing accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I usually leave work at 5:30 pm.

D. Air Traffic Controller

I work a set shift pattern, which includes early shifts that start at 6:00 am. I relieve the night shift and take over one of the four control positions in the tower. We work as a team, controlling aircraft movements. In winter, we handle around 1,000 movements per day, and more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I often use the time to review new air traffic requirements. It's essential to be fully alert in this job, so even if I'm not feeling well, I wouldn't hesitate to take a day off. I find the work stressful, and it can take time to wind down after a shift. I hope to become watch manager and eventually general manager of the airport.

E. Shop Manager

If I'm on an early shift, I leave the house at 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system and ensuring someone is available to man the till. I coordinate staff lunches and breaks and spend the morning helping customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be frustrating when they ask for recommendations based on reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' reps visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the upcoming months. I consider how many copies of a particular title the shop is likely to sell. I make sure new titles are delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm, and I close the shop two days a week.

F. Financial Analyst

I listen to the news at 7:00 am and take a taxi to work at 8:45 am. I start by contacting our freelance reporters to find out what's happening in the region I'm responsible for. I assess financial risk for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. **Career Power: How to Lead Effectively**

What makes a good leader? A leader is someone who inspires others, brings about change, and shows the way forward. Leadership is not just about being intelligent or having a certain physical appearance. According to Pat Dixon, author of "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace", leadership is about motivating others to achieve their goals. A good leader should be able to communicate clearly and confidently, and inspire enthusiasm in others.

John van Maurik, director of a Leadership in Management course, believes that everyone has the potential to be a leader, but it's about recognizing and developing that potential. We may not always realize our leadership abilities, but with the right circumstances, we can flourish.

In the workplace, leadership is essential for effective management. A good leader can motivate and support their team, while a bad leader can make employees feel unimportant and unvalued.

Leaders and managers are different. Managers follow established rules, while leaders create their own path. A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can transform an organization.

Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can benefit you. Here are some tips:

* Identify your passions and convictions and take the lead when you feel inspired.
* Recognize your leadership abilities and start thinking of yourself as a leader.
* Experiment with different leadership styles and learn to delegate, motivate, and communicate effectively.
* Set goals and work towards them, and be willing to learn from your mistakes.
* Be visible and accessible to your team, but also know when to step back and let others take the lead.

Remember, leadership is not just about giving orders, but about inspiring and motivating others to achieve their goals.<|eot_id|>

F. **The Longest Day** This war epic has an all-star cast and four directors. It's a big and ambitious film, but it's better suited to the big screen. The early scenes drag on, and the video version is not as impressive as the original.

This summer, I quit my job and decided to travel. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm actually nervous. I've done some traveling before, but this time I'm more anxious because I'm older and have more responsibilities. I've been working for a while, got married, bought a house, and got used to earning a salary. But I realized that I was sacrificing my own happiness for my job.

When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. Many of my friends are now married with children and they envy my freedom. I'm no longer in a relationship, and I have no burning career ambitions. I feel like I should make the most of my freedom, even if it's just for my friends' sake.

I'm nervous about making arrangements, like finding someone to rent my flat and organizing my finances. I'm also worried about adjusting to a simpler way of life and feeling out of place among younger travelers. I've discovered that many Britons in their late twenties and thirties are leaving their comfortable lives behind to travel.

Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that people are realizing that adventure is within reach if they're brave enough and organized enough. She believes that this is a sign of a more stable society where people are less concerned with material things and more concerned with living a balanced life.

For some, traveling is a chance to reassess their lives and take a break from their routine. For others, it's a way to escape the monotony of their daily lives. Whatever the reason, many people are taking the leap and traveling the world.

Georgina McGuiness took a break from her journalism career and felt out of touch with the latest technology. She tells the story of how she transformed her home into a workspace. Last Christmas, I turned 37 and realized that if I wanted to get back into journalism, I needed to catch up with the times. My CV showed that I was stuck in the 1980s, when typing on a typewriter was the norm. Most job ads asked for experience with desktop publishing, which I didn't have. I felt like I was a dinosaur. I was the family technophobe - even using a pocket calculator was a mystery to me. I knew I had to act quickly. I won a competition and got a laptop and a personal computer for my family. We plunged into the world of computers and soon became familiar with terms like "cyberspace" and "surfing the internet." We started chatting with strangers online and the children even set up their own mini-office in the kitchen. I was hesitant at first, but I managed to learn the basics. I started freelancing for a magazine and soon realized that I had the best of both worlds. The computer has helped me become more organized, and I can now easily keep track of my income and expenses. I can also research stories online and connect with other journalists and writers. However, working from home can also have its drawbacks - I sometimes feel isolated and struggle to balance work and family life. Despite this, I'm proud to be part of a growing community of home workers who are taking advantage of the convenience of working from home. According to a report, most people who use computers at home are well-educated, own a personal computer, and have a modem. I'm glad to say that I fit this profile. Who knows, maybe one day I'll be publishing my own magazine from home.

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1 on the CEFR:

The end of print newspapers might take some time. The idea of transition can be scary for some and challenging for others. However, transition means moving from one stage to another in a smooth and gradual way. But when it comes to newspapers switching to online, it's a different story. The process is uncertain and uncomfortable because it may not be a gradual change at all.

Everyone knows that print newspaper sales are declining, while online newspaper visits are increasing. The latest figures show that The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian, and many other newspapers have seen a decrease in sales between 8% and 10% over the past year, but their online traffic is growing. However, there are some things that don't quite add up.

For example, if print sales are declining, perhaps the problem mainly affects newspapers? But the World Association of Newspapers has reported that global circulation rose by 1.1% last year, with sales in Asia making up for the decline in the West. News and current affairs magazines, which you might expect to be affected by the digital shift, actually saw a 5.4% increase.

Similarly, book sales are also showing mixed results. While e-readers like Kindle are popular, sales of physical books have only decreased by 0.4% over the past six months. It seems that people are using both digital and print media.

The idea that young people are abandoning newspaper reading is also exaggerated. According to the National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people between the ages of 15 and 35 still follow the main national dailies. Different countries also have different stories to tell. For example, while Britain has seen a 10.8% decline in recent years, Germany has only seen a 7% decline, and France has seen a 3.1% decline.

These varying trends may suggest that the situation is more complex than the digital revolutionaries assume. The assumption that online advertising would pay for the transition and make online newspapers successful has not come true. In fact, digital advertising on newspaper websites is actually declining. Many US newspapers have built paywalls around their content, but the best way to attract paying readers seems to be by offering a joint package of print and digital access. Print is also a crucial tool for selling internet subscriptions, and its advertising rates are much higher than online rates.

However, maintaining both an active website and an active print edition is difficult, complex, and expensive. Newspaper companies still have a strong brand identity in print, but it's harder to get noticed online.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
To simplify the text for a learner of English at the C1 level, I will make some adjustments to the vocabulary, sentence structure, and tone while maintaining the factual content. Here is the revised text:

**Photographing People**

People are often the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with someone in it is usually more engaging than the same shot without a person. However, photographing people can be challenging because you need to consider not only technical and artistic aspects but also the subject's actions, gestures, and expressions.

**Group Shots**

When taking group photos, avoid straight lines and suggest that people stand at different angles and distances. You can also ask some group members to sit or kneel at the front to ensure all faces are visible.

**Posing for Pictures**

People tend to stiffen up when in front of a camera, making their poses unnatural. To relax your subject, suggest a comfortable position, such as folding their arms or putting them in their pockets.

**The Right Approach**

Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when it's obvious you are, as this can create tension and hostility. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, and some may even be flattered. However, they may become self-conscious and need direction.

**Eye Contact**

A picture gains impact when the subject looks directly at the viewer. Ask your subject to look into the lens, but not necessarily to smile. This can be challenging, so remind them just before taking the shot.

**Candid Concentration**

An alternative to direct eye contact is to have the subject focus on something within the frame. This can be easier and more natural, and the viewer can follow their attention to another part of the picture.

**Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures convey more about a person than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, anger, tears, or thumbs-up, as they can tell a story instantly.

**Situation Interest**

While isolating a figure or face can be impactful, the background or environment can add interest and context. Try to exclude irrelevant details and blur them if necessary. Ensure the subject is not overwhelmed by the background.

**Interaction**

When photographing people interacting, look for contact between them, such as eye contact or physical contact. This can create a compelling image.

**People and Places**

When taking pictures of people in a location, use a standard or wide-angle lens and move back to capture the whole scene. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera and compose the shot so the group forms a foreground interest without obscuring the background.

**To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Consider why you want to take the picture. If you want a clear portrait, ask the subject to pose against a well-chosen background. However, candid shots of events as they happen can be more lively and memorable.

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist who creates paintings that trick the eye into thinking they are real. She doesn't like to talk about herself, but her work speaks for itself. In this interview, she opens up about her passion for trompe-l'oeil and her approach to her craft.

Janson has been an artist for 16 years, after studying art and graphic illustration. She used to work as an illustrator, but it wasn't fulfilling, so she joined a specialist decorator and started doing trompe-l'oeil. She loved it and eventually set up her own business.

Her experience as an illustrator helped her develop her observational skills and attention to detail, which are essential for trompe-l'oeil. She believes that no one can teach you how to do trompe-l'oeil, it's all about observation and practice.

Janson is self-critical and often downplays her abilities. She thinks that the moment you think you've mastered something, you should stop. She's also honest about her limitations, admitting that she can't paint bread to look like bread.

Despite her humility, Janson has a string of impressive commissions and has worked on several large projects, including a ceiling in a castle. She's very particular about her work and makes sure it's personal to each client.

Trompe-l'oeil has to be clever and engaging, Janson believes. It has to draw you in and then hold your attention. She loves working with clients and getting to know them, which helps her come up with ideas.

Janson is grateful for her clients and the freedom they give her to create. She's always busy and has a reputation for being talented, but she doesn't like to brag about herself. She thinks that things that shout too much can get boring, and she prefers to let her work speak for itself.

'Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success

The way we work is changing. We are no longer judged solely on our intelligence, skills, or experience. Instead, we are evaluated on how well we interact with others and handle ourselves in the workplace. This new standard is used to determine who will be hired, promoted, or passed over. It also helps predict who will be a top performer and who may struggle.

The new rules focus on social skills and personal qualities, such as initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are the 'people skills' that make up emotional intelligence. Emotional intelligence is the ability to recognize and manage your own emotions and those of others, and to use emotions to guide your thoughts and actions.

In today's workplace, where job security is uncertain and jobs are changing, personal qualities are becoming more important. Emotional intelligence is no longer just about being 'nice' or 'friendly'. It's about being able to manage your emotions and those of others to achieve common goals. It's about being able to work well with others and make tough decisions when necessary.

Many companies are recognizing the importance of emotional intelligence in the workplace. They are realizing that it's not just about technical skills or IQ, but about being able to work effectively with others. In fact, studies have shown that emotional intelligence can be developed and improved over time. With practice and experience, we can become more skilled at managing our emotions, motivating ourselves, and building strong relationships.

Emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, but it is an essential component of being successful in today's workplace. It's a skill that can be developed and improved, and it's essential for achieving stability and success in our careers.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1 (CEFR):

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a 2,000-year-old technique that comes from traditional Chinese medicine. It combines herbalism, massage, diet, exercise, and other methods to treat various health conditions. Western doctors have been interested in acupuncture's ability to relieve pain.

**How it works**

Traditional Chinese medicine sees health as a balance between the mind, body, and spirit. It believes that energy, or Qi, flows through the body along special pathways called meridians. When Qi is blocked or imbalanced, it can cause weakness or illness. An acupuncturist will examine a person's pulse, tongue, and overall health to identify imbalances. They may also use fine needles, warmth, or pressure to stimulate the flow of Qi.

**Pain Relief**

Acupuncture is used to treat various types of pain, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. Some people use it as a last resort when other treatments haven't worked. Acupuncturists claim that it can also help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain experienced by terminally ill people.

**Modern Use**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for centuries, it has only recently been used as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery. This has helped convince some Western doctors that acupuncture is more than just a placebo effect. Today, acupuncture is used in various operations, including open heart surgery.

**Effectiveness**

While it's difficult to run clinical trials for acupuncture, studies have shown that 50-80% of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists claim a similar success rate, acknowledging that it may not work for everyone.

**A Holistic Approach**

Acupuncturists view pain differently than Western medicine. They consider a person's overall health, lifestyle, and environment when diagnosing and treating pain. They believe that understanding the underlying causes of pain is key to achieving long-term relief.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others reject traditional Chinese theory and focus on scientific explanations. When choosing an acupuncturist, it's essential to select someone who will refer you to a medical doctor if necessary.

I minimized changes to the factual content while simplifying the language and sentence structure to make it more accessible to a learner of English at level C1.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1 (CEFR):

P.D. James, a renowned crime writer, has a calm and authoritative demeanor. However, beneath this exterior, she has a complex and imaginative mind. She is often compared to a headmistress of a girls' school, but she reveals that her shyness hides beneath her confident exterior.

James' detective, Adam Dalgliesh, is modeled after herself, but as a man. Like his creator, he prefers to work alone, especially when writing. She values her privacy and can write anywhere as long as she has it.

Despite her success, James is humble about her position as Britain's best-known crime writer. She admires the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, who writes under the name Barbara Vine. James' bookshelf is filled with works by female authors, including Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, as well as male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.

James' writing career began late in life, with her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, published when she was 42. Born in Oxford, she grew up in Cambridge, where she met her husband and later set the scene for one of her novels. Despite facing challenges, including her husband's illness and the need to work long hours to support her family, James found time to write and developed her organizational skills.

Working in administration for the National Health Service and the Home Office helped James develop her skills, including her ability to work with forensic science research and juvenile crime. Her experience with corpses during her time in forensic science did not inspire her writing, but rather the construction and structure of a crime novel. James wanted to write a serious novel about human beings, and she found that the detective story format allowed her to do so.

Writing detective stories, she says, is a way of bringing order to disorder and confirming the sanctity of life, even in difficult situations. She believes that nobody likes violence, and her writing reflects this.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

"The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is a growing field that can reveal a person's character. In some countries, employers use graphologists to analyze job applicants' handwriting to determine their suitability for a job. Graphology is also used to identify certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and to understand psychological states and emotional disturbances.

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist, believes that handwriting can indicate a person's intelligence, social class, and even their potential for certain medical conditions. She argues that handwriting can be used to assess mental ability, personality, and potential career paths.

Marne claims that graphology can also be used to identify criminal tendencies, as most criminals have disturbed handwriting. She believes that handwriting can reveal whether someone is honest, manipulative, or reliable, and even predict whether they are likely to commit a crime.

In addition, Marne says that handwriting can be used to detect heart and lung problems, as well as emotional upsets. She notes that a change in handwriting over time can indicate a serious medical condition.

Marne also believes that handwriting can reveal other psychological characteristics, such as deviousness, sensitivity, and confidence. She emphasizes the importance of studying handwriting for at least six years to become a skilled graphologist.

However, some doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the value of graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic ability, and writing style, and has no other significance."

A new survey says that a happy and healthy workforce is crucial, and it all starts with a good office environment. We visited four different offices to see how they compare. Our expert panel consisted of a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist.

Office A: This advertising agency office is quite simple. It has no central heating or ventilation, and the windows open directly onto the street. Despite this, the employees seem happy and content. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and windows or using electric radiators. This might be because they're a small, close-knit team with no bureaucracy to deal with.

Office B: This news service office is comfortable and well-maintained, thanks to a no-smoking policy. The employees have good chairs, good lighting, and a varied work schedule. However, the office space is impersonal and unstimulating.

Office C: This bank office is a mixed bag. The air is fresh, despite the presence of smokers. The employees are supportive of each other and well-equipped with technology. However, the office is uninspiring and could be improved with more visual interest.

Office D: This newspaper office is a disaster. The air conditioning is poor, the space is cluttered, and it's dusty. The furniture is old and uncomfortable, and the carpets are dirty. The employees seem stressed and driven by deadlines.

The experts' verdicts on each office are included below:

Office A: The building health consultant says it's simple but works well. The ergonomist notes that the furniture is varied and not always comfortable. The occupational psychologist praises the variety of work and the office space.

Office B: The building health consultant says it's comfortable and well-maintained. The ergonomist praises the good chairs and lighting. The occupational psychologist suggests improving the layout and adding visual interest.

Office C: The building health consultant notes that it's a mixed reaction. The ergonomist says it's standard and uninspiring. The occupational psychologist praises the supportive team and technology.

Office D: The building health consultant says it's difficult to find anything good to say. The ergonomist says the furniture is old and uncomfortable. The occupational psychologist suggests a good tidy-up, recognition of individual success, and improved air conditioning.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Chewing Gum: A Sticky Story

Chewing gum is a popular habit in the United States, where people chew 12 million sticks every day. But where did this custom come from? Let's take a journey through time to discover how an ancient practice became a big business.

In ancient Greece, people chewed a resin from the mastic tree to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists later adopted this habit, chewing resin from spruce trees. In the 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

In the late 1800s, a new type of chewing gum was discovered in the Central American rainforest. The sapodilla tree produced a milky substance called chicle, which made gum that was smoother, more satisfying, and more elastic. This led to the development of a whole industry based on chicle.

However, cultivating sapodilla commercially has been difficult. Today, only a few people, called chicleros, still gather chicle from the trees. They face many challenges, including poisonous snakes, insects, and a fly that lays its eggs in their ears and nose. Despite these dangers, chicleros continue to tap the sapodilla trees, carrying the liquid on their backs to a camp where it is boiled and made into bricks.

As the demand for chewing gum has grown, manufacturers have turned to synthetic alternatives to reduce costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, they have also developed new ways to market their products, making claims about their benefits, such as reducing tooth decay. Research continues to improve the texture and flavor of gum, with new ingredients like glycerine and vegetable oils being used.

Interestingly, a significant amount of land in the United States is dedicated to growing mint, which is used in two of the most popular chewing gums in the world.

Despite some negative points, Sue praises some of the hotel's staff, including Emma and Trudy, who are knowledgeable about the hotel's history. The hotel's food is also good, which means it can keep its two-rosette food rating. Sue suggests that the hotel needs to improve its desserts, which sometimes collapse.

Sue's job is to give honest feedback to the hotel owners, which can be difficult. She has to deal with complaints from hotel owners who are unhappy with her reports. Despite this, she is required to send a written report to the hotel owners and to make sure that they make the necessary improvements. The hotel owners pay an annual fee to be included in the guide, but it is worth it because it helps them to attract more customers.

Overall, Sue's inspection of the Globe Hotel is not all negative. She suggests that the hotel needs to make some improvements, but she does not recommend that it lose its red stars. Here is the simplified text, minimizing changes to the factual content:

**The Seven Summits**

I, Doug Scott, share my experience of climbing the highest peak on each continent. Here's my story:

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**

We were in a snow cave 91m below the summit when my partner, Dougal Haston, started talking to our Equipment Officer, Dave Clark. I thought this was strange, as only Dougal and I were present. I realized I was talking to my feet due to oxygen deprivation. We spent two days on the summit ridge, and I realized I had to get a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**

We climbed Mt. McKinley, known as the most treacherous mountain in the world. We humped equipment and food up to the base and climbed a new route, which was the first time a major new route had been climbed in this way.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**

We got lost in the jungle on the lower slopes of Kilimanjaro and found a rock pool with luminous arrows and a trail of rubbish. We took the Umbwe route to the surrealistic summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**

We joined a guide and his party on the Polish Glacier, which was swept by strong winds. We decided to miss out on the glacier and take the standard route to the summit.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**

We guided a team to Vinson Massif, which was a matter of financing the cost of getting there. We left Britain in November 1992 and traveled to the South Pole. The winds were strong, and visibility was low, but we reached the summit within 8 hours.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**

Our team assembled in St Petersburg and climbed Elbrus by cableway to 3,900m. We walked to the refuge at 4,200m and then to the summit, which was another kilometre-long ridge away.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**

We hoped to establish a new route and spend time with the aboriginal Dani people. We left our hut and walked to the jungle, where we climbed the mountain and reached the summit by 11 am.

**Mission Accomplished!**

Note: I've kept the original text's tone and style, but simplified some sentences and phrases to make it more accessible to learners at the C1 level.<|eot_id|>
