Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Susan Shepherd is a well-known artist, famous for her beautiful flower paintings. Her garden, which surrounds her house, is the main source of inspiration for her work. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, including tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are quite wild and spread themselves around the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path, which runs from east to west, have a harmonious balance of color, shape, and structure. This is partly due to the previous owners, who were keen gardeners and left many plants behind. Susan also inherited the gardener, Danny, who has been a great help.

Susan prefers to paint individual flowers rather than the garden as a whole. She might occasionally paint a group of flowers together. She usually picks the flowers and then takes them to her studio to paint. 'I don't set up the whole thing at once,' she says. 'I take one flower, paint it, and then bring in another one and build up the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a few years to finish.'

Susan's busiest time is in the spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies bloom. She also enjoys watching the gradual decay process, as the flowers change shape and form. For example, when she brings tulips into her studio, they change shape and open up over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany at school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside. She didn't like garden flowers, but was fascinated by the way wildflowers grew in unexpected places.

Now, her garden is home to many plants from far-off lands, which seem to thrive in their new environment. Susan has a relaxed attitude to her garden, letting her children (or grandchildren) play freely, as long as they don't cause any damage. With two upcoming exhibitions and a constant supply of subject material, it's been difficult for her to find time to work in the garden lately. However, she knows that to stay connected to her art, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

The garden had made the house look private, but now the room seemed too bright and the furniture looked old and worn. The house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, was now visible and didn't look very nice. Pelham didn't like the way it looked, but his wife, Molly, thought they should buy a new sofa to improve the room.

Here is the simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

We had lived in our valley for 16 months when we first realized the dangers that could threaten our survival. It was a year when the storms came early, before winter even arrived. Until then, we felt safe and sheltered in our valley, protected by the hills. Suddenly, snow started falling. Within a day, it was 15 centimeters deep and blocked our lane. The streamside path became slippery and dangerous. However, the snow was much deeper on the nearby hills, where the wind was fierce. We felt only occasional gusts of wind in our valley, but we knew we had to be concerned. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but not a major problem. It was the river, the Ryburn, that worried us most. Normally, it flowed gently, but if the flow of water from the hills hadn't been controlled by dams many years ago, we might have faced a different situation. As the snow started to melt, we watched the clouds gather over the hills to the west. Dark clouds extended over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was to come. We began to focus on the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washing away, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and approaching danger level. Finally, it happened - the reservoir overflowed for the first time in years. The water surged over the edge of the dam and poured into the stream below. The river became furious, pouring almost horizontally down to its lower stretches. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it, lashing at its banks. We prayed that it would stay below its wall for three days. Fortunately, our prayers were answered, and the dam held, allowing the waters to subside. In the past, the river had flooded nearby villages in similar circumstances. Now, with the dam, we can enjoy the huge clouds and be thrilled by the river's power without fear. Thanks to the dam, we can feel safe in our valley.

Here is the simplified text for a C1 level learner:

I've been a film critic for The Front Page newspaper for the past ten years. Before that, I did some freelance work reviewing books, films, and radio programs. I met Tom Seaton, the arts editor of The Front Page, who had a background in radio and television. He hired me, but he wasn't a traditional journalist. He had an unusual idea: a team of critics would cover various art forms, including books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would meet weekly to discuss our choices and have guests join us. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper. However, the team idea didn't work out, and we ended up working individually by phone. The public preferred to associate a reviewer with a specific area, so I focused on film. I'm grateful for this arrangement, which allows me to write in-depth pieces about one film each week. I wouldn't want to be a traditional film critic, reviewing every new release. That would be too routine. Instead, I can use my space to develop my arguments and make the most of my writing. But what's the purpose of a film review? I don't think it's to tell people what to watch. People usually choose films based on the stars, publicity, or director. Loyalty to a particular genre or style can also play a role. Rarely does someone change their mind about a film after reading a review. So, what is a film review for? I don't feel responsible for being "right" about a movie. I just need to present my opinion. I'm not a judge, and I wouldn't want to be.

The ideal candidate should enjoy long-distance running (regular 15 km sessions), swimming (preferably in cold water), and cycling (with a love for 10 km rides). Triathlons are becoming increasingly popular, with athletes swimming 1.5 km, cycling 40 km, and then running 10 km without stopping. But what motivates these athletes to push their bodies to such limits? Melanie Sears, a 17-year-old with excellent academic results, has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenge. When she swims 1.5 km, she jumps on her bike, still wet, and cycles 40 km before running 10 km, which can be exhausting. But she finds it enjoyable and worth the effort.

Melanie started triathlons at 14 and won the junior section. She entered the National Championships, but despite having the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not finish well. Here is a simplified version of the text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

"The Joy of Collecting: A Hobby Shared by Many

As a collector, I have always been fascinated by the world of collecting. It's a world where people come together to share their passion for collecting, and one in three adults indulge in this hobby. Collecting is a journey that involves passion, enthusiasm, and a sense of accomplishment.

For as long as humans have existed, people have collected things. From ancient times, people have gathered objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Today, people still collect objects for their beauty, rarity, or sentimental value.

I have been collecting for as long as I can remember. My first collection was of stones I found in my parents' garden. As I grew older, I started collecting other things like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My love for collecting only grew stronger as I discovered the joy of searching for rare and unique items.

Many famous collectors have inspired me, including the Duc de Berry, who had a 'room of wonders' filled with natural and artificial curiosities. Catherine the Great of Russia, on the other hand, collected over 4,000 paintings. However, you don't need to be rich or powerful to start a collection. I've collected items as diverse as tulip bulbs and china cups, and I've even searched for rare American rag dolls.

What I find most fascinating is the way collections change hands and the stories they tell. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet can give an object great value. As objects become popular among collectors, their value increases. The toys of the 1950s, for example, are now considered an investment.

As a collector, I've experienced both the joy and the sadness of losing a collection. One of my collections was destroyed in a fire, and it was hard to see the remains of my treasured items. However, I've learned that the joy of collecting comes from the journey, not just the destination."

His friends started to tease him, calling him a coward, and eventually, they got tired of waiting and walked away. Michael remained on the roof, feeling embarrassed and ashamed.

He stayed there for nearly an hour, watching the sun set behind the lake. His clothes were soaked with sweat, and he was late for dinner. When he finally got home, his stepmother scolded him for being late and told him to stay in for the night. Michael was deeply ashamed and wanted to avoid his family.

'Chocolate has a long history that dates back to ancient times in South America. Today, it is a global industry worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter, making it a big business. In fact, eight per cent of all chocolate sold is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate than at Easter. The cacao tree, from which chocolate is made, is an evergreen plant that grows in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of the tree contains 20-40 seeds, which are dried to become cacao beans. These beans are used to make chocolate. In the past, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money and to make a bitter drink called xocoatl. The Spanish liked their chocolate mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread to the rest of Europe. In the 17th century, chocolate houses were set up in European cities, where people would gather to drink chocolate. Until the late 19th century, chocolate was made by melting solid blocks of chocolate in hot water. In 1826, a Dutch inventor created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it today was invented in 1847 by a British company that combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate and sugar. Later, a Swiss company added milk solids to create milk chocolate. The British chocolate market was once dominated by French companies, but Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar became a popular alternative. Today, chocolate manufacturers are looking for new ways to attract customers, such as creating chocolate-based snacks like ice cream and soft drinks. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still feeling the effects of a price crash in the 1980s, which forced many small-scale farmers out of business.'

At 83, Peter Cooke has mastered the art of creating beautiful objects from shells. He's been doing it for ten years and is still enthusiastic about it. He shows me his work in his apartment, and I'm impressed by the delicate and unique objects he's made.

Cooke is not worried about people finding his work boring. He's charming and passionate about his craft, and that shines through in his work. He points out a pair of shell-covered ornaments above the fireplace and says, "I don't mind if people don't buy them. I've grown used to them, and they're lovely to me."

Cooke didn't start making his art to sell it commercially. Friends encouraged him to have an exhibition, and 70% of the objects sold. His second exhibition just opened, and the pieces are priced between £225 and £2,000.

Cooke is honest about the prices, saying there's no one else who creates work like his. He believes that when he stops making art, people will want his pieces because there won't be any more. He wishes he had started earlier, but he's still producing beautiful work.

Cooke's unique style is due to his attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry. He's developed his own method, using materials like cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid to create his art. He travels to find beautiful and tiny shells, often going to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines.

Cooke defends himself against accusations of harming the environment by saying that he only collects dead shells and that the sea breaks them up anyway. He argues that he's not harming the environment and that his art is a way to appreciate the beauty of nature.

Make sure to label your luggage clearly with your home and holiday addresses, as well as the flight numbers. Charlie James has been trying to capture the beauty of the kingfisher on film for many years. He has spent countless hours waiting patiently near the bird's favourite spots, often hiding behind a blanket or a hideout. It took him four years to get his first good picture, but he has continued to work hard and has become a renowned wildlife photographer. Charlie's passion for the kingfisher has even led him to miss school and become an "academic failure". However, his talent and dedication have been recognized, and he has worked as an advisor for a nature magazine and as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, Charlie wants to make a film about the kingfisher that will show its beauty and majesty without any words. He believes that the simple approach is the best way to convey his feelings about the bird. Despite his success, Charlie knows that there is still much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.

Andrew Constantine, 31, won a major conducting competition in 1991 after two failed attempts. He believes the competition gave him many performance opportunities and a chance to work with a well-known conductor. However, he is still trying to shake off the "competition" label.

Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, loves the long rehearsal period that comes with opera productions. She started conducting in her late 20s and credits her teacher, Sian Edwards, with helping her develop her skills.

Roger Vignoles, 48, discovered conducting by chance, but found it fascinating. He started his career as a musician and worked with experienced conductors before being asked to direct a production from the piano. He was surprised by how much he enjoyed it and is now open to new opportunities.

Wayne Marshall, 32, was noticed by conductor Simon Rattle and soon found himself conducting a musical in London. He had to deal with some professional musicians who were not taking the performance seriously, but he stood firm and got the best results. Marshall has never formally studied conducting, but has learned from his experiences and is determined to succeed.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

"Variations on a Theme: Choosing the Best Theme Park for Families

If you're thinking of taking your children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options to choose from. We asked five families to test the best ones. Here are their experiences:

Fun Island: The Burns family

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might seem dull by comparison. But we were pleasantly surprised. The park caters well to younger children, so our three-year-old didn't feel left out. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's a special dodgems ride for the very young, which was a hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only criticism is that the park lacks atmosphere and the scenery could be better. However, the staff are very helpful and the park is clean, well-organised, and secure.

Wonderland: The McMillan family

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which had small replicas of famous buildings at his level. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places where we could rest our feet. The landscaping is perfect, and the staff are friendly and helpful. There's something for everyone, including adults.

Adventure World: The Jeffree family

After seven hours, we still felt there was a lot to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a fantastic trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut most of the time, they said they enjoyed it. Their favourite ride was Running River, which makes you think you'll get soaked, but you don't. For younger children, Toy Land is great fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but were relieved to find they were too small to go on it! The park is well-designed, so even queuing for rides isn't boring. It's spotless, and the staff are great.

The Great Park: The Langridge family

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm a bit of a scaredy-cat, but even I enjoyed myself. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts off calmly and then becomes a lot of fun. We queued for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over before we knew it! I wouldn't go on the Big Leap, but if you're brave, it looked great. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

Fantasy World: The Break-all family

According to the park's advertising, there's 'No Limit to the Fun', and we certainly felt that was true. The park has Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, which dominates the skyline. Ben thought it was the most terrifying ride, but Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 metres above the ground, was even worse! There are a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for a couple of them, but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes were mixed. Some were great with the younger children, but the welcome wasn't always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't have told the kids we were leaving early."

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

Running a business in the countryside

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside.

A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She moved to the countryside with her husband and children. She wanted to work from home, so she started her business. It was difficult at first, but she was careful with her money. She has four full-time employees and a turnover of over £200,000 a year. Most of her customers are local, so she doesn't have to deliver her work.

B. Maggy Sasanow is a designer who works from home. She used to work in art at university, but after she got married, she moved to the countryside. She started her own business designing greetings cards. She sells them to museums and galleries. She works alone, but she doesn't advertise her business. People find her through word of mouth.

C. Delia Turner started a curtain-making business eight years ago. It was successful at first, but then the economy declined and she had to lay off her employees. Now she works with her husband and a few freelancers. She has to be careful with her finances and adapt to changes in the market.

D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside because it was cheaper than living in London. She enjoys the freedom to work at her own pace. She has to deal with clients from all over the world, so she has to be available at odd hours.

E. Meg Rivers started a cakes-by-post business at home. She makes fruit cakes using high-quality ingredients. She started getting orders from friends and family, and soon she was sending cakes all over the country. She now employs six people and has a turnover of £250,000 a year. Her biggest challenge has been managing the financial side of the business.

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is very special because all the sons are talented musicians. Their father, John, makes musical instruments. Not many families have a member who writes and plays music, as well as someone who makes the instruments.

When their son Paul was 10 years old, he started playing the cello. His parents, John and Hetty, wanted to get him a good cello, but it was very expensive. So, John decided to learn how to make one himself. He took evening classes for three years and made his first cello for Paul. Paul used it until recently.

John is now a full-time instrument maker and makes about 12 violins a year. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul started with the piano, but soon switched to the cello because he loved the way the cellist in his father's group played. Huw, on the other hand, started with the piano and later discovered his own talent for composition.

Paul has had a successful music career, winning the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and becoming the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the age of 20. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music.

Huw is also a talented musician and composer. He will be performing his string quartet at the Wigmore Hall, while Paul will be playing Elgar's Cello Concerto on television. Their parents, John and Hetty, will have to be busy keeping track of their sons' many musical activities.

The National Trust is a charity that aims to protect the British countryside. I visited the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and met Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust. Gareth thinks that to be a good warden, you need common sense and good communication skills. You need to be able to work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders.

Gareth grew up on a farm in the Lleyn Peninsula and worked there until he got married. When he applied for the warden job, about 80 people applied, but his local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job. Although he didn't have formal training, Gareth's experience farming with his parents has been useful. He can deal with farmers and understand their problems.

Gareth's farming background has also helped him with the physical demands of the job, such as building fences and planting trees. Since he started working for the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He used to collect flowers, butterflies, and birds' nests when he was a child, but now he realizes that farming has affected the countryside. He thinks that farmers and conservationists used to be at odds, but now they are working together.

Gareth's job involves conservation, managing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He enjoys seeing projects completed and working with the public, but sometimes he finds it difficult to deal with people who are rude and demanding. Despite this, Gareth likes his job and thinks that common sense is essential for being a good warden.

If you have common sense and enjoy working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. However, it may take a while to get a job on the Lleyn Peninsula.<|eot_id|>

She's very focused on her training and doesn't notice the people around her. Her goal is to be at her best for the Championships.

This will be her fourth World Championships, and she's expecting a big challenge. There will be 27 teams participating, and England will have home support, which is a big advantage. Kendra wants to improve the reputation of netball in England and feels that the team will face more pressure than usual.

Their first game is against Barbados, a team they have beaten in the past. However, Kendra knows that the World Championships will be tough, with no rest between games and only one chance to win. She believes that players need to be mentally and physically prepared to perform at their best.

Kendra has been playing netball at the top level for 15 years and has seen the sport become faster and more competitive. She thinks that players need to train like world-class athletes and have a strong mental attitude. As captain, she aims to support and encourage her teammates.

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully and has decided that this will be her last big event. She's likely to coach young players in the future, but for now, her focus is on the World Championships. When she leads her team onto the court, she may have a tear in her eye.

Here is the simplified version of the text for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

**Specialist Music Schools: How to Support Gifted Musicians**

Not all parents know how to help their child develop their exceptional musical talent. Some children may even struggle in school due to the lack of support for their musical abilities. This is where specialist music schools come in. These schools provide a unique environment where gifted children can develop their skills with the guidance of professional musicians.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools that cater to children aged 7-18. These schools offer a balanced education, with a focus on music and a limited academic programme. Students spend most of their day practicing music, including individual lessons, orchestras, and theory classes. They also have private practice rooms and work with experienced teachers.

The schools are independent and have small classes with a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living at the school full-time. This allows them to focus on their music and be surrounded by like-minded peers.

However, there are some drawbacks to consider. The schools are expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age.

Some experts question whether it's wise to separate musically gifted children from their peers at such a young age. This can lead to stress and pressure to perform. However, the schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer support when needed.

Many former students have benefited from the high-quality music education, but some have expressed concerns about the limited academic programme. Musically gifted students are often highly intelligent and may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

It may be better to wait until the child is older and can make their own decisions before considering a specialist education. Alternatively, they may thrive in a regular school with a strong music department or by combining their music training with a normal school routine.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1 (CEFR):

Susan Shepherd is a well-known artist, famous for her flower paintings. Her garden, which surrounds her house, is her main source of inspiration. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, particularly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are quite wild and spread quickly, but the two long flower borders along the path that crosses the garden from east to west are carefully planned. This is partly due to the previous owners, who were keen gardeners, and partly due to the gardener, Danny, who has been working in the garden for a long time.

Susan focuses on painting individual flowers rather than the garden as a whole. She often takes a flower from the garden, paints it, and then adds another one to the painting. Sometimes it takes her several years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times, when the tulips and poppies are in bloom. She loves the way the flowers change shape and color over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany at school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside. She didn't like garden flowers when she was younger, preferring wildflowers that grew in unusual places. Now, she has a diverse range of plants from all over the world in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude towards the garden, letting her children play freely as long as they don't cause damage.

With two upcoming exhibitions and a steady supply of inspiration from her garden, Susan has been busy lately. She now employs an extra gardener, but she still likes to get her hands dirty to stay connected to her art.

Here is the simplified text for a C1 level learner:

As a chalet girl, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch's work is never done. She is 24 years old and works for a company in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah's job involves cooking and cleaning for guests who come to ski and stay in wooden chalets. She graduated from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art.

Sarah doesn't consider being a chalet girl a career, but rather a way to spend a year or two before settling down. She enjoys the social aspect of the job, meeting successful people every week. Sarah doesn't live in the chalet, but walks a mile to work every morning. She starts her day at 7 a.m. by having breakfast and then preparing breakfast for the guests. The guests get a full breakfast with a variety of options.

After breakfast, Sarah clears up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She considers cleaning the rooms the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is free to go skiing. Sarah loves skiing and tries to do as much as possible. She usually skis until 4:30 p.m. and then returns to the chalet to prepare dinner.

Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually served by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. She sometimes stays and chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be left alone. Sarah meets her friends in the evening and they go out to local bars and restaurants.

On Sundays, Sarah's day starts earlier than usual, with breakfast for guests who are leaving at 7 a.m. She then spends the morning cleaning the chalet and doing the weekly shopping. In the afternoon, she prepares tea for the new guests and helps them with any equipment they need. She then has dinner and sometimes goes out with friends, but often has an early night due to her busy schedule.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Title: Changing Lives with a Stranger

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at Marie Claire magazine's offices. She usually wears a uniform at work, so choosing what to wear was tricky. Mandie visited a photo studio and press previews before lunch. The zoo is a peaceful place, but at Marie Claire, everyone was rushing around. Mandie was surprised to see how stressed some of the fashion team members were. She enjoyed her job at the zoo and didn't want to leave.

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at London Zoo. She wore her usual leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo provided a green polo shirt for her to wear. She got very dirty while working and thought Mandie would be packing clothes in the cupboard. By the end of the day, Alice was tired but had a great time.

Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team and presenter Alan Titchmarsh. Karen enjoyed being outdoors and working in the fresh air. She was surprised by how much physical work was involved and realized that landscape gardening wasn't as romantic as she thought. She didn't plan to give up her job as a nurse.

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. He expected to find it difficult, but he was surprised to find that he didn't get overwhelmed. He enjoyed the friendly atmosphere among the nurses and felt it was a more "girlie" environment than his usual male-dominated workplace. Charlie felt that his job was not as important as nursing.

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day as a cabin crew member with Ryanair. She felt different when she put on the uniform and was surprised by how much attention she received. On the flight to Paris, she gave out magazines to passengers and felt self-conscious. On the return journey, there were 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn't sit still. Lucy was happy to be back in the gym with one adult to look after.

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was nervous about trying exercise, but was surprised by how much attention each person received. She was surprised to see that some trainers didn't eat healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. Sonia wouldn't swap her job for this, but it inspired her to join a gym and try to be healthier.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Trying to get your writing published? Margaret Stubbs, an expert in publishing, is here to help. Many readers of this magazine ask, 'I've written a story/book. Where can I send it?' Before sending your work out, it's essential to research the market and understand what publishers are looking for. To do this, read widely and often. Visit your local library and bookshops to get an idea of what's currently being published. This knowledge is crucial, as new publications and editors are constantly emerging.

When you're starting out, it's normal to be unsure what kind of writing you want to do. For example, you might be interested in writing short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories and read recent issues to understand the type of stories they accept and the target audience. This will help you tailor your writing to meet the editor's needs.

Many writers send me their work, asking if it's worth sending out. As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but I have to be honest – most new writers are not yet ready for publication. It's rare for someone to get published with just one story. Success often comes after years of experience in the publishing industry.

When you do finally send out your work, start writing more immediately while you wait for a response. The more you write, the better you'll become, and your confidence will grow. Don't be afraid to make mistakes – use them as an opportunity to improve. Also, avoid sharing your work with others until you're happy with it.

Remember, every successful writer has faced rejection many times before achieving success. To advance your writing career, consider taking a creative writing course or joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other writers. Treat yourself as a writer and make writing a daily habit.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1 on the CEFR:

On the last day of a difficult year, I was waiting for my train at the Baltimore railway station. There were more people than I expected, and the usual feeling of calm and order was missing. Elderly couples with matching luggage sat on the benches, and students were scattered around, leaving their bags on the floor. A well-dressed man was walking around, talking to strangers. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came to a girl with long blonde hair, who was standing near me. I had been thinking I might like to talk to her. The man asked her if she was going to Philadelphia, and she said she was going to New York, but heading north. He thanked her and moved on. Now I was curious about him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, and when she said she was going to Wilmington, he didn't say anything and walked away. I straightened up and walked closer, pretending to be interested in the platform. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. I understood why; he probably thought I was unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then walked away. He looked stressed. He asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia, and she said yes. He asked her for a favor, but she seemed hesitant. I stopped listening and looked at my wrist (I don't wear a watch). The man must have sensed her unease, because he promised it wouldn't be difficult. They were announcing my train, and people were moving towards Gate E. The man told the woman that his daughter was flying out that afternoon for a study year abroad, but she had forgotten her passport in Philadelphia. He had sent her back to the station and would have someone bring her passport. The woman sympathized with him. I thought it was a strange story. Why didn't he go himself? He said he couldn't leave his wife alone, as she was in a wheelchair. I thought this was a poor excuse. I looked at the two of them, and the man was holding a padded envelope, stapled shut. I thought to myself, "Be careful, lady!"

My son Gary is a famous TV chef, and I'm proud to have played a part in his journey. I believe everyone deserves a chance in life, and Gary got his chance with cooking. I took a chance on a restaurant, and it turned out to be a great opportunity. When I first saw the place, it was in a bad state, but I saw potential. It reminded me of my childhood, when my mother had to work in a factory and I was left alone. I wanted to make sure my family had time for each other, so my wife took care of the children and did the accounts while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant and always made time for family meals. This had a positive impact on our children, Gary and Joe. They're both confident and have a strong sense of responsibility.

Gary was a lively child and always had a passion for cooking. He started helping out in the kitchen when he was young and quickly showed a talent for it. By the time he was 15, he was as good as any of the other cooks, and sometimes even in charge. He had a natural flair for cooking and was always eager to learn. When he told me he wanted to do work experience as part of his school course, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary has also developed a passion for music and now plays the drums in a band. My advice to him is to focus on one thing at a time and not spread himself too thin.

Gary went to catering college at 17 and quickly proved himself to be a hard worker. On his first day, he completed all his tasks in an hour, impressing his instructors and classmates. I'm extremely proud of him and his success on TV. I've always told him that hard work and dedication are key to achieving his goals, and he's taken that to heart. As a parent, you can only hope that your children will take some of the advice you give them, and Gary seems to have listened and learned from his experiences.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1 (CEFR):

Finding a flat in Dublin at a reasonable price was like finding a rare gem. The best way to find one was through personal connections. If you knew someone who knew someone who was moving out, it often worked. However, if you were new to Dublin like Jo, you had no personal connections. You had to stay in a hostel and search for a place. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to work there. She didn't think about why she was moving there. It was assumed that she would go to Dublin by everyone she knew. Who would stay in a small town when you could have a big city life? That's what everyone had said for years.

Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, and she would be safe. Her father said he hoped the hostel was warm, as hostels were often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn't know they were talking about her, as she answered an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own TV, share kitchen and bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. Please, please let it be nice, let them like me, and let it not be too expensive!

The flat was not in a queue, as it was more 'Third Person Wanted' than 'Flat to Let'. The fact that it said 'own TV' made Jo wonder if it was too luxurious for her, but the house didn't look fancy. It was an ordinary red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and a friendly girl with a college scarf, who had already applied, was coming down the stairs. 'This place is desperate,' she said to Jo. 'The owners are awful.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said the girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobbish girl leaving? I can't stand people like that.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around and made a face and giggled and then said, "Is this all there is to it? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't want someone like that here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline had a colorful shirt on, but even it was not as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, Jo noticed with surprise. She had seen them on the street, but never talked to one before. 'I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I rang,' Nessa said they were just about to have a cup of tea. She produced three mugs; one had 'Nessa', one had 'Pauline', and the other had 'Other' written on it. 'We'll get your name on a mug if you come to stay,' she said kindly.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Dolphins are loved by many people. We enjoy watching them in aquariums, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their situation is critical. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of the species.

Dolphins are highly intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They are often featured in films and TV programmes, such as Flipper and Darwin in Seaquest. However, these shows do not reveal the reality of dolphins' lives in polluted and overfished oceans.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has decreased by up to 89,000. Despite their popularity, dolphins are not well protected by law and are not cared for in special marine reserves.

There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide. In European waters, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoises. The first two are rarely seen near the coast, while the last two are found near European shores.

Bottlenose dolphins are social and used to be common in British waters. However, they are now mostly found in Scotland and Wales, and their skin injuries indicate that they are stressed.

The decline of dolphins is linked to overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing industries. Dolphins are also at risk of getting caught in fishing nets, which can be invisible to them. In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches, with signs of net entanglement.

Dolphins can also be affected by pollution in the sea, such as pesticides, which can build up in their bodies and be passed on to their young. Another threat is noise pollution, which can disturb dolphins and disrupt their social behavior.

This will help you maintain a balanced posture and improve your overall appearance.

Stretching exercises are also essential for flexibility and ease of movement. Regular stretching can help prevent muscle tears and injuries caused by overuse. Aim to stretch four to five times a week to maintain a flexible and fit body. A well-rounded exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period."

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but it's also important for her research on underwater volcanoes. She's been studying them for three years, and it's an incredible feeling to see them up close.

Rachel has had a few scary moments, like when she went on a dive with an American team and there was an unexpected explosion. But she's also experienced moments of wonder, like when she first saw the underwater volcanoes. She feels privileged to be able to explore the deepest parts of the ocean, and she's grateful to be able to share her discoveries with others.

**Four Young Sports Stars Share Their Lives**

A. Darius (runner) I've always been into sports. I tried many, but athletics was my best. When I was 14, I had a trial with a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My biggest achievement was representing my country in the youth team and getting a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was a shame. I had hoped for sponsorship, as training is expensive. I train at home during the winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun, with great facilities and nightlife. You need to be disciplined, though. If friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. Dedication is key in this sport. My goal is to compete in the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

B. Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you see the same people everywhere you compete. Professional surfers are very serious and often the best waves are early in the morning, so you have to give up late nights. I don't mind, but I do love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. But it's worth it, as without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money involved, I'll go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it in the long run, as winning the championship meant I got to present a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

C. Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a great time. We're traditional and celebrate a win in style. It's been said that we act a bit childish when we're out, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often focus more on where we go out and what we do there than on our racing results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's great to get back and do normal things with friends from other walks of life. You can't live and breathe the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known within the sailing community, but I'm not recognized on the street often. I'd hate to become a celebrity. I reply to every fan letter I receive, even if it takes time.

D. Tomas (tennis player) It's great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Despite that, I still get a thrill from being recognized by fans when I'm out and about. However, it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we split up, I guess. You have to make sacrifices in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. I'm content to focus on my game now and catch up on other things in life once I retire, as that comes relatively early in this sport.

Taking children shopping can be a nightmare for some mothers. They want everything they see, from the latest sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. Parents often struggle to say no, feeling guilty about buying unhealthy food and worried about the impact on their children's health. However, saying yes can lead to feelings of regret and frustration. Research shows that children make a purchase request every two minutes while shopping, and parents spend over £150 million a year on advertising that targets children, mostly on TV. Children often don't understand why they can't have what they want, and the persuasive advertising campaigns can be overwhelming.

According to Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance, parents are concerned about what they feed their children, but their ideas about healthy food are not always accurate. A dialogue between parents and children is essential, as children may only get information about products from TV advertising, which can be misleading. Parents feel they are competing with the advertising industry and are forced to disappoint their children repeatedly.

Some parents find it stressful to decide which demands to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but still feels unhappy about managing their shopping requests. Another mother has taught her son to be critical of advertisements and they spend time reading labels together. This has reduced conflict while shopping.

Parents also admit to being inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets because they're bad for his children, but they buy unhealthy treats for themselves. It's hard to be consistent and it depends on their mood. Supermarkets could help by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. This could lead to more customers and reduce parent-child conflict.

"Ice Skating: A History and Guide

Ice skating has a long history, dating back thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. People used these bone skates until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In the past, skating was a popular activity among the upper classes in Scandinavia. In the early 20th century, skating was seen as a stylish and exclusive activity, but it gained popularity after the 1924 Winter Olympics, when a young skater named Sonja Henie introduced a more athletic approach.

Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism. It requires balance, control, and physical fitness. To start, you need to learn how to balance and control your body. Keep your knees bent and your weight centered. For beginners, relaxation is key. Make sure your heels are almost touching and your feet are turned outwards. When moving, make small movements with your feet.

It's also important to learn how to fall safely. Even experienced skaters fall sometimes. To avoid injury, stay relaxed and try to roll with the fall. To get up, use your hands to get into a kneeling position and then stand up.

Once you're comfortable on the ice, you can try different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, distance, and speed skating. The best way to start is to learn figure skating and then move on to elementary freestyle. Most ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn the basics.

To improve your skating, practice regularly and focus on relaxation and flexibility. Warm up before you skate and do exercises to loosen your legs, back, and shoulders. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness. Skating can help improve your balance, coordination, and overall fitness. It's a great activity to combine with swimming or jogging for a well-rounded fitness program."

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of English at the C1 level:

Chris Greener is the tallest man in Britain, standing at 228 cm. When he was 14, he wanted to join the navy, but his teacher asked him what he wanted to be, and Chris replied, 'The flagpole on a ship!' The teacher had a point, as Chris was already quite tall at that age. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimetre. This means that more and more people are growing taller.

Interestingly, this doesn't mean that we are creating a new'super race'. Instead, we are returning to our natural height, which was typical of our ancestors 40,000 years ago. Professor Chris Stringer believes that we are becoming like the Cro-Magnons, who lived during that time.

For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and meat. They based their diet on 85 different wild plants. However, around 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, and this had a negative impact on human health and physique. We started to eat more carbohydrates, such as wheat, rice, and maize, and this led to a range of health problems.

In recent times, scientists have discovered that when people switched from a hunter-gatherer diet to a farming diet, they became underfed and underdeveloped. They developed diseases like tooth decay and became more prone to illness. However, farming allowed more people to live in one place, which led to population growth.

Today, some countries, like the US, Holland, and Japan, are returning to a more varied diet, which is resulting in people growing taller. The average height in these countries is now around 177-180 cm. However, this trend is not without its challenges. For example, furniture and clothes are not designed for taller people, and this can cause problems.

Scientists are unsure what the maximum height of humans could be, but some believe it could be as high as 193 cm. However, they also note that, as a species, humans are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, humans were slightly taller and rounder, which helped them keep warm. Since the climate warmed up, we have become slightly thinner and smaller. As the planet continues to warm up, we may shrink even further.

The growth of humans could be offset by global warming, which could mean that we may not continue to grow taller indefinitely.

Note: I have maintained the factual content of the original text and only simplified the language to make it more accessible to a C1 level learner.<|eot_id|>

Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape familiar yet different. I still visit the area today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary, which was my first attempt at writing.

I also enjoy a miniature train ride from Hythe to Dungeness. The scenery is not spectacular, but there's one special moment when the train passes through back gardens, giving me a glimpse into people's daily lives. I like the ordinary landscapes that make me look closer and search for something interesting.

The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast with few visitors. The beaches are hard to reach, and the coast is known for its shipwrecks. There are scenic walks and valleys to explore, and we stay in a family-run accommodation in the village of Southole.

My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a vast and remote moorland perfect for hiking. It's an unknown area with few residents and visitors. I discovered it by chance when I was a student and have been returning every year. Having a child makes these visits even more special.

I also have a special connection to Glenthorne, a house in Britain that I purchased. It's a place of peace and tranquility, where I can reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon, where I would cycle around the moors and village streets. Glenthorne is a magical and secluded house where I can escape the noise and distractions of everyday life.

"We're a family of animal lovers. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work with exciting news: she had found a beautiful pine snake. 'Can we keep it?' she asked. I agreed, but only for a night. We had a special tank for temporary visitors, and I thought it would be a great opportunity for the kids to learn about snakes. I was running late, so I quickly boiled some water as I rushed home. Just as I was about to start cooking, I heard my sons' cries for help from their bedroom. I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, chasing Bianca, a white mouse we had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino had the mouse's feet in his jaws and was running around the room, trying to find a way out.

I joined the chaos and tripped over something or someone, ending up on the floor. As I looked up, I saw the snake had escaped from its tank and was slithering across the floor. I crouched down, ready to grab it, but it was too fast. The snake and I were being jumped over by the cat, mouse, and kids, who were all screaming and hissing. I managed to catch Domino and free the mouse, but not before the snake had made its escape.

Encouraged by my success, I decided to take a closer look at the snake. It was surprisingly strong and agile. Eventually, I managed to subdue it and release it into the garden, pointing it towards a nearby tree. To my surprise, it curled up around my shoulders, seemingly content to stay for the winter. We stood there in the fading light, my four kids, me, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, explained that the snake probably liked the warmth and comfort of my body. I asked the kids to gently encourage the snake to move on, and it slowly made its way up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of tail disappeared, my three-year-old son, Clay, summed it up for all of us: 'That was one big snake!'"<|eot_id|>

'Letter Writing: A Lost Art?

In today's world of emails, texts, and social media, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is unique and special. There's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it's from, and the joy of reading the contents. I've been writing letters for as long as I can remember. My mother always encouraged me to write my own thank-you letters for birthdays and Christmas presents. When I moved away to London to study medicine at 18, I would write to my mother every week, and so would she. My father would also write occasionally, and his long, funny letters were always a treat. Most of the letters from home were about everyday events and news about my parents and their friends. Of course, we would also make phone calls, but it's the letters I remember most. I've also received letters from my boyfriends over the years. I've found that writing helps me express myself more easily than talking. I love receiving letters with birthday or Christmas cards, especially those with beautiful stamps. I've had penfriends from all over the world, including Sri Lanka, Australia, and France. One of my penfriends and I have even met up twice and exchanged visits. I believe that letter writing is an important way to connect with others and maintain relationships. My children are also carrying on the tradition, writing their own thank-you letters and even exchanging letters with their penfriends in Texas. I think it's essential to keep letter writing alive and not let it become a lost art.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1:

Taking children to the supermarket can be a challenging experience for many parents. Children often want everything they see, from the latest sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. Parents feel guilty when they agree to their demands, knowing they might be buying unhealthy food. At the same time, saying no all the time can be frustrating and lead to arguments. Research shows that children make a purchase request every two minutes when they are taken shopping. The food industry spends over £150 million a year on advertising directly to children, mostly on television. This can be effective, as children are often unclear about why their parents make certain choices and are influenced by persuasive advertising.

Parents worry that they are competing with the advertising industry and are forced to repeatedly disappoint their children. The Independent Television Commission prohibits advertisers from telling children to ask their parents to buy products, but the intention is still to persuade them to buy something. Some parents find it stressful to decide which demands to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she has learned to discuss food with her children and has even "brainwashed" her son into being critical of advertisements.

Parents admit they can be inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's requests. For example, they might refuse to buy sweets for their children because they are bad for them, but then buy unhealthy treats for themselves. Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less without their children, the thought of shopping without constant demands would likely attract more customers.

In the past, climbers used to go to mountains to practice. However, as the sport developed, it became important for top climbers to stay fit throughout the year. Since cliffs were often unusable during the winter, they would climb on brick-edges or stone buildings to keep their skills sharp. Many sports centres started building walls specifically for climbing, using special bricks with edges to hold on to.

Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, built the first climbing wall in the 1960s by setting natural rock in concrete. This design was copied by many sports halls across the country in the 1970s. However, these walls had limitations. They were only vertical, and climbers got bored with the same old holds.

In the 1980s, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a new material that could be molded into shapes like those found on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers got bored. French manufacturers also created panels that could be attached to steel frames, allowing for overhanging walls and endless combinations of holds."

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1:

Becoming an actor is a challenging career choice. Many people think it's a risky profession because there are more aspiring actors than there are job opportunities. When you decide to pursue an acting career, some friends may think you're crazy, while others may offer different advice. It's a personal decision, and you're responsible for your own success.

There's no easy way to become an actor. You won't find a straightforward path or a guaranteed job after completing your training. It's a combination of luck and talent. However, there's always a demand for new faces and talent, and the profession can be exciting, glamorous, and rewarding.

I've been asked to define talent many times. I believe it's a natural ability combined with imagination. The latter is difficult to assess, as it's closely linked to an individual's courage and confidence in their work.

Actors often struggle to explain why they want to act. In theatre, the most important thing is the moment when an actor connects with the audience. This connection drives all actors to perform, whether on stage or screen.

When asked how they've succeeded in the profession, actors usually shrug and say they don't know. They may know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they never take their success for granted. They know that their fame can be short-lived, and disappointment is their greatest enemy.

Actors often try to protect themselves from the stress of competing for roles and the risk of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected, and it's a possibility from the start of their professional career. As an actor, you need to show that you're available, willing, and talented enough for a job. Ultimately, it's up to you to care enough to succeed.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'The average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. This means that more people are growing taller every year. However, this does not mean that humans are becoming a new species. Instead, we are returning to our natural height. For most of human history, our ancestors ate a varied diet that included many different types of food. They gathered fruits, vegetables, and nuts, and occasionally hunted animals. This diet was much healthier than the one we have today.

About 9,000 years ago, people started farming, which led to a decrease in the variety of foods people ate. Today, most people eat a diet that is based on just three main foods: wheat, rice, and maize. This diet has had negative effects on our health and physical development.

In the past, people who ate a diet based on farming were often undernourished and unhealthy. This was because they were not getting the nutrients they needed from their food. In some cases, people who started eating a diet based on farming became sick and underweight. However, farming allowed more people to live in one place, which led to the development of cities and societies.

In recent years, some countries have started to eat a more varied diet again, which has led to an increase in average height. In the US, the average height is now 179cm, in Holland it is 180cm, and in Japan it is 177cm. However, there are still some problems with this trend. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size as they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers are having to make new sizes to accommodate the taller population.

It is unclear how much taller humans can get. Some scientists think that the average height could reach 193cm, but it is also possible that it could level off. Another issue is that as the planet warms up, humans may actually get smaller. This could mean that the growth in height could be offset by global warming.'

'Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are turning their childhood game into a successful business. They're sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, reliving their childhood memories of playing pichenotte, a game that their grandfather introduced to their family from Quebec, Canada. The game is unique, and they loved playing it with their family every weekend and holiday. When they moved to New Mexico, they continued to play, and visitors were fascinated by the game, which was unknown in the region.

Three years ago, Dave decided to make a new pichenotte board, which turned out to be a beauty. When friends and relatives showed interest, he realized that the game could be popular. He took one of the boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe and was surprised by the reaction. People were initially skeptical, but soon they were hooked. When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched and discovered that it was probably inspired by a similar game called carroms from India, which was adapted into a game called squails in Britain and then brought to Canada by British emigrants.

Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version of the game, which can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces, or pucks, which are flicked across a wheel-like board using the middle or index finger of one hand. The game is a test of skill, with different point values for different areas of the board. The game usually lasts only two minutes.

The brothers took their game to markets and craft fairs, where it became a hit. They started making more boards and selling them online. The game's popularity grew, and they even started holding championships and creating a trophy called the Lord Pichenotte Cup. With the game's popularity spreading, the brothers decided to turn their passion into a full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and started producing high-quality boards made of birchwood and mahogany. Each board weighs 12kg and is lcm thick, making it very durable. They're available online for $595 each.

Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are optimistic about the game's future. They're happy to spend their free time playing the game that they hope will make their fortune.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1 (CEFR):

British newspapers often publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. While pop stars may occasionally pose for photographers, this is not typical. More commonly, individuals in the public eye suffer damage when their private moments are captured on the front page. However, very few people complain to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to deal with such issues. Rarely, if ever, do these pictures serve the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help detect a crime? How did a famous actress's picture on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress had good reason to complain, as she was in a place where people expect privacy. Yet she didn't take action. The PCC should investigate these cases.

The PCC could take the initiative in investigating such cases, but there are several problems. How would they decide whether to launch an investigation? Should they approach the person involved and encourage them to make a complaint? What if the person still refuses to take action? Additionally, celebrities and members of royalty might expect their stories to be taken up, and then be outraged if they're not. The role of the PCC is too enormous to monitor the entire British press. There's also the embarrassment factor to consider. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, they might not want the further embarrassment of an investigation. Most people just want to move on with their lives.

One comedian was also a victim of the press, when his honeymoon photos were published. He didn't complain, fearing the newspaper would run the pictures again with a new story about his reaction. People believe they'll become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to see an easy solution to this serious problem.

In two and a half years, she's become more confident and her job has changed a lot. Each participant had designed four different kites, which were judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency.

After the festival, I visited Adnan's home and had a cup of cold milk tea and some fish crackers. He invited me to help him rebuild his kite, but I had to decline. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur. I took a wrong turn and ended up at a river, where I took a boat to the other side. I noticed a sign pointing to a footpath into the forest and decided to follow it. The path was steep and slippery, but I eventually reached a tented kitchen and some bamboo huts, where I met Baba, who offered me tea. I decided to stay the night, despite the insects and strange noises. The next morning, I woke up to a breathtaking view of the mountains. Later, it rained, and I slid down the hill, worried about my car being swept away. Fortunately, it was still there, covered in mud. Everywhere I went, people were friendly and curious, asking me questions about my origin and age.

I kept the kite Adnan gave me as a souvenir, and I will always remember my trip to Kelantan for its kite festival and the kindness of its people.

**What kind of shopper are you?**

We all go shopping, but we don't all shop in the same way. Abby Edwards asked a few people about their shopping habits.

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**

I'm an impulsive shopper. I love buying things and often go shopping with my boyfriend. We both love finding bargains.

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**

I'm not a big fan of shopping. My husband usually buys our groceries, and I only go shopping with my kids when they need new clothes. I don't like spending money on myself.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**

I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and try to get in and out as quickly as possible.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**

I like to shop occasionally, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time in stores.

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**

I don't enjoy shopping at all. I dislike looking for clothes because it's stressful and I never find what I want. I rarely have to buy clothes, so it's not a big problem.

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**

I'm a happy shopper. I like going out with friends and trying new things. If I see something I like, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**

I'm a careful shopper. I like going to stores, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and don't get carried away.

'Gallery News Easter Quiz for Children

During the Easter holidays, children can participate in a fun quiz about surprises at the Gallery. The quiz sheets are available at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be directed to 14 surprising paintings and asked questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

New Picture

The Gallery has acquired a beautiful still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is painted in bright colours on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this type in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It was donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. The painting is now on display in Room 25.

Special Exhibition

The exhibition 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century' is now open in the Sunley Room. The exhibition features works by three Spanish painters of this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes works by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

Lecture Series

The lecture series accompanying the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez, and on 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

Gallery Restaurant

The Gallery is pleased to announce that it has improved and expanded its restaurant service. The new kitchens offer a wide range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

Visitor Information

Free guided tours of the Gallery take place every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's most famous paintings and showcase the entire collection of European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.'

'Money What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are just like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can exchange money for something else. A five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a printed piece of paper that costs almost nothing to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money as we know it today. There were no banks or shops. In those days, Mr. Green, the farmer, would exchange the corn he had grown for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each of whom had something the other wanted. Over time, most societies developed their own currencies, making it easier for people to exchange goods and services. As different currencies began to join together, we now use national currencies today.'

Nene Park offers a range of activities for families, including golf courses, a caravan site, and a miniature railway. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with lakes, picnic areas, and a nature reserve.

Wansford Station is home to a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. Visitors can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open on days when the train is running. There is a £2.00 entrance fee for adults and £1.00 for children.

**Filming Location**

'The Ghan Train: A Journey Across Australia

I took the Ghan Train from Darwin in the north to Adelaide in the south. The train crosses the Australian continent, passing from the warm north to the cold south. It's often called the 'Ghan', but it's not exactly famous for being on time. The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide was first proposed in the 1920s, but it wasn't until recently that the line was completed. The train is designed for speeds of up to 115 kph, but it's not a high-speed train. There are few stops and most passengers are tourists. The train was originally built to transport goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's southern cities via Darwin and the train would be faster and cheaper than taking a ship around the continent.

As I boarded the train, I could see that everyone was excited for the journey. The majority of my fellow passengers were Australian pensioners. Our first stop was Katherine, where some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train and got off at Alice Springs, where I joined a small group for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock). We walked around the rock and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers break their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs wasn't particularly interesting, just flat land with cattle. But on the third day, we reached the foothills of an area near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train didn't quite live up to its promises, it took me to some of Australia's most amazing sights.'

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a learner of English at level C1:

Climbing Ben Nevis, Scotland's highest mountain, is a challenging experience. Thousands of people attempt the climb every year, but it's not for the faint-hearted. The mountain's northerly location means the weather can be extremely cold. Climber Keith Hewitt recounts his first winter climb up Ben Nevis.

In February, Keith and his group set out to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge, a six-hundred-metre ascent. They planned to camp halfway up the mountain for three days. The group was well-prepared, carrying tents, sleeping bags, and crampons for their boots. They also brought safety equipment, including lights, hard hats, and extra clothing.

Despite the perfect weather forecast, the group felt a sense of nervousness as they began their climb. The track was steep, and Keith, the weakest member of the group, had to rest more frequently. The others would wait for him to catch up, but then they would continue on. Keith realized that he would need to train more before attempting a climb like this again.

After two hundred metres, the group reached the start of Tower Ridge, a narrow path that winds its way to the top of the mountain. The ridge is only a metre and a half wide, with a steep drop on either side. The group knew they had to be careful and concentrate to make it to the top.

After seven hours of climbing, they finally reached the summit. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. However, on Keith's first climb, a mist had rolled in, obscuring the view. The descent was just as challenging as the ascent, as the group had to navigate using a map to avoid dangerous slopes. Keith was relieved to be safely back in their tent, where he could finally relax and enjoy the experience.

When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus I was on. I would like to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me that day, and praise their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'
