The hotel is built in stages, with each part opening to visitors and guests as it is completed. The building process usually takes about 7 weeks to finish.

The hotel is built outside, so the temperature inside is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it's colder outside. Guests can borrow warm clothing like overalls, hats, and gloves, but it's also a good idea to bring your own warm clothing. You can buy warm clothing and other necessary items on the Icehotel's website when you book your visit.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. It's easily accessible by bus from Kiruna airport or train station.'

The Short Story Society was established in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in Britain. Our main goal is to support writers in the UK.

Magazines

We publish several excellent magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by well-known British writers and provides opportunities for new writers to get their work published. Our other magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and keeps readers informed about writing events, competitions, and festivals.

National Short Story Competition

We run the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. The competition is open to anyone aged 18 or over and accepts short stories on any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for members, but non-members pay a fee of £5. The competition runs from April to October each year. The top 10 entries will be published in our annual book of short stories, and the winner will receive a publishing contract for their own collection of short stories.

Education

For nearly thirty years, we have been taking writers into classrooms, providing children and teachers with new ideas and building confidence in their writing. Our current projects include the Young Writer of the Year competition, which is open to writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and are invited to attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

The Writers' Cafe

Our Writers' Cafe is a social hub where members can relax and enjoy freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffee, and cold drinks. We also host monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. The cafe is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm from Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members receive discounts on selected products and events.

Joining the Society

We have members from all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or over is welcome to join. If you're interested in joining The Short Story Society, click here to fill out a registration form.

Some people have expressed concerns about the dangers of free-diving, but Tanya emphasizes the importance of safety and proper training. Conserving her energy is crucial, as fatigue could compromise her performance.

When not preparing for events, Tanya makes public appearances to promote sports products and support environmental organizations. She has also worked on research projects and documentaries. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, Tanya spent much of her childhood swimming and exploring rockpools to observe marine life. She believes her life today is a realization of her childhood dreams. As a well-known figure, she feels people are more likely to listen to her environmental concerns. **A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

The MV Lady Ivy May, a 'hotel ship', operates on the Douro River in Portugal. The ship can accommodate 160 passengers in comfortable cabins with private bathrooms and air-conditioning. On board, you'll find a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

Day 1: Arrive at Oporto Airport and transfer to the ship. Spend the night on board.

Day 2: Visit Oporto in the morning, then return to the ship and depart for Entre-os-Rios. The journey takes about four hours.

Day 3: Continue up the river and stop at Peso da Regua in the evening. Enjoy dinner and try local specialties.

Day 4: Take a bus to Lamego, an ancient town with a rich history. Visit the cathedral, churches, and a museum with an impressive collection of art and artifacts. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrower, and you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish frontier at Barca d'Alva. Return to Tua by coach and enjoy the scenic views.

Day 6: Drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a breathtaking view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch and then take a scenic train ride to Regua, where the ship will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real, then return to the ship for lunch and sail down the river to Oporto. Spend the night on board.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto in time for independent sightseeing and shopping before your return flight to London Heathrow.

The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. The city itself marked its 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter in 1994. This charter allowed Norwich to become a city and govern itself independently.

Although Norwich is relatively small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of around 150,000, it was once the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and prosper for centuries, earning a reputation for having many churches (as many as there are weeks in a year) and pubs (as many as there are days in a year). Today, while there are fewer churches and pubs, the city has a thriving university, the University of East Anglia, which was established in 1964. This has brought a new wave of students and a diverse range of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centres.

The city is also home to a football team, known as 'The Canaries', although the origin of the name is unclear. Another popular attraction is the modern shopping centre, 'The Castle Mall', which was built on the site of a large hole in the city centre. The construction process, which took over two years, involved moving nearly a million tons of earth to create a city park with water features and hundreds of trees. Despite this, the old open market remains in the heart of the city, next to the new development, and continues to thrive.

The Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, is filled with a kaleidoscope of colours. This is the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta, a nine-day event that takes place every year. The festival started in 1972 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. Initially, there were about a dozen hot-air balloons, which took off from a car park in the city. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, over 1,000 balloons from more than a third of the countries in the world are expected to attend the festival at its new out-of-town location.

What to See and Do The pilots use radio communication to coordinate their take-offs, and they light up their balloons at the same time, creating a spectacular sight known as a 'balloon glow'. This is a great opportunity to take amazing photos, but you need to arrive just after sunset or before 5:30 am to see it. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes, shapes, and colours, including those shaped like animals, cartoon characters, and famous brands. Kids will love it! You can also take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Alternatively, you can take a cable car ride from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest such ride in the world, and enjoy a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks displays on the opening and closing evenings of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box This local wind pattern creates ideal conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds, and the gentle currents of air at different heights allow skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons.

Practical Tips Buy your tickets in advance to avoid long queues. Wear layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool at night and early morning, but hot during the day. Don't forget your camera, flashlight, and sun protection. If you're not a digital photographer, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night-time pictures.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the C1 level:

'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD

In the late 1800s, gold was discovered in Alaska, a state in the north of the United States. Many people moved to the area to search for gold. A town called Iditarod was established, which grew rapidly. It even became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. However, during the winter months, it was difficult to deliver essential supplies to the town because the rivers and ocean froze. To solve this problem, a winter route was built in 1910. Teams of dogs pulling sleds used this route to transport mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. The route was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for the dogs to travel across Alaska.

The teams stopped at 'roadhouses' along the way, where the drivers could rest and feed themselves and their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s, when planes replaced dogs and boats as the main means of transportation. However, the dogs had one last important job in 1925. A disease called diphtheria broke out in the city of Nome, and the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. The pilots were not confident about flying in such cold weather, so it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took 20 teams just six days to complete the journey. The famous journey was completed by Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska in search of gold, and his dog Togo. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go any further and saved the team from falling into icy water. As a result, the diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as the famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level C1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Welcome to Antarctica Sightseeing Flights! Before booking your flight, please read this information carefully.

We take tourists on a 12-hour flight from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. The flight is during the brief Antarctic summer. We don't have fixed dates for next year yet, but if you book now, your deposit is transferable if the date changes.

Frequently Asked Questions

How long is the flight?

The average flight is 12 hours. We usually see sea ice and icebergs about four hours into the flight. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the remaining time flying back.

What do I do on the flight?

On the way to and from Antarctica, our experts who have lived on the continent give talks about the environment and history. You can also ask them questions. A camera next to the pilot shows you a pilot's-eye view of the flight.

Will I get a window seat?

All passengers get two boarding passes. At the halfway point, you'll switch to the seat shown on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While we're over Antarctica, we encourage you to get up and move around the plane to see the sights.

What if the weather is bad?

We have 17 approved flight plans. Our captain chooses the direction with the clearest views based on the satellite cloud picture.

Will I see penguins and wildlife?

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, so we can't see them in detail from the plane. We don't land on Antarctica for environmental reasons. To see wildlife, you'd need to join a boat tour.

Can I take photos?

Yes, all cameras are welcome! We even have fun photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold-weather clothes.'

I made minimal changes to the factual content to ensure that the questions associated with the text remain answerable. I simplified the language, breaking up long sentences and using more straightforward vocabulary to make it more accessible for a C1 learner.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Generally, increase your stopping distance by double on wet roads, triple on snowy roads, and even more on icy roads. By staying in control of your car, you can avoid trouble.'

'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE

In the past, London had no police force. A few elderly men used to patrol the streets at night, but they weren't paid very well. Around 300 years ago, London was growing rapidly. The city was dirty and many people were poor. Crime was a big problem, and people stayed indoors as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding started a group of people to fight crime. They were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very large and needed more police officers. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force was established, with 3,000 officers. Most officers walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police are well paid, and those who still ride horses receive even higher pay.'

The introduction of jet engines in the 1950s greatly increased their speed.
